data.title: France in £10bn takeover of London power network
data.description:
French utility giant Engie unveiled a $14bn (£10.3bn) deal to buy the entire power distribution network for London and the South East of England.

France’s Engie, a renewable electricity and green gas producer, said it had agreed a deal to buy UK Power Networks from groups controlled by Hong Kong billionaire Sir Li Ka-shing – boosting its exposure to net zero power.

The utility company plans to finance the acquisition through a combination of about €5bn (£4.4bn) in debt and securities, and approximately €4bn in asset disposal by 2028. It also said it would raise up to €3bn equity through an accelerated book building.

The deal will mean that the power networks of London and the South East will be controlled by France, which already owns a significant portion of Britain’s nuclear power infrastructure.

All five nuclear power stations in the UK are operated by France’s EDF – which together provide around 12pc of the country’s total electricity.

EDF is fully owned by the French state after the government vowed to renationalise the electricity company in 2023 to help secure the country’s nuclear future. It is Europe’s largest renewable energy producer.

The state owns a stake of about 24pc of Engie, making it the anchor shareholder with significant voting power.

The purchase of UK Power Networks – which supplies Heathrow as well as other airports including Gatwick, Stansted and London City – comes as France attempts to lessen its exposure to traditional gas networks.

In July 2025, EDF confirmed a 12.5pc stake in Britain’s Sizewell C project and said it would invest up to £1.1bn in the scheme. The UK Government is due to retain a stake of just under 45pc.

In January, think tank Citepa reported that France was successful in reducing its greenhouse gas emissions by 1.6pc last year, down from 1.8pc in 2024 and 6.8pc in 2023.

Politicians have urged the country to go quicker, with Monique Barbut, the French environment minister, having said recent efforts were “not enough”.

Fear of Chinese influence

Sir Ka-shing’s CK Infrastructure Holdings bought UK Power Networks in 2010 for £5.5bn.

The bid to purchase the power company reportedly arose from a last-minute offer of a higher price because the group decided that Britain’s high inflation had lifted the value of UK Power Networks.

The company is also owned by sister business CK Power Assets, both of which hold a 40pc stake. The last 20pc of the group is owned by CK Asset.

The sale of the business by Mr Ka-shing follows concerns over Chinese influence across crucial infrastructure in Britain.

Mr Ka-shing has previously been accused of political “collaboration” with the Chinese state. His companies declined to comment on the claims at the time.

More recently, though, officials in Beijing have turned on the Hong Kong billionaire after he was pressured by the Trump administration to sell two key ports on the Panama Canal.

It is the country’s largest electricity distributor, serving up to 8.5 million households and businesses.

UK Power Networks runs Heathrow Airport’s internal electricity network and was named as “a key stakeholder” in the National Energy System Operator’s official investigation into a fire that led Heathrow Airport to shut temporarily last year. The company had no role in causing the fire.

Basil Scarsella, the chief executive of UK Power Networks, said: “By joining Engie, we continue to be part of a global energy leader with the financial strength, industrial capabilities and long-term vision to support our next phase of development as UKPN embarks on a period of significant investment in our network to enable economic growth in London, the South East and East of England.”

Catherine MacGregor, Engie’s chief executive, said: “This transaction will both enhance the Group’s growth trajectory and reduce our risk profile, providing more visibility on future earnings.

“It also enables us to reinforce our position in the United Kingdom, a key country with a stable regulatory framework and clear [decarbonisation] targets.”

data.title: If John Lewis can’t build houses, then Britain’s property market really is doomed
data.description:
John Lewis’s surprise move into housebuilding was conceived during a very different era. It was the height of the pandemic and with John Lewis in the grip of a financial crisis, Dame Sharon White, then the boss – just months into the job – was under immense pressure to dream up new revenue streams.

Profits had crashed, leaving the sacred staff bonus at its lowest for nearly 70 years. At the same time, 1,300 jobs were being axed, debt had ballooned to £2.4bn and Dame Sharon had warned that it could take five years for the illustrious organisation to recover.

Diversifying away from traditional retail and utilising John Lewis’s existing property assets made great sense – at least in principle – as Dame Sharon sought to generate 40pc of annual profits from non-retail ventures by 2030.

What’s more, here was one of the country’s pre-eminent ethically led organisations proposing to help solve the housing crisis with thousands of genuinely high-quality homes. In many ways, it was an inspired idea.

Yet less than five years later, the great John Lewis housebuilding dream is dead – crushed by a lethal combination of planning red tape and spiralling costs.

It has been greeted in some quarters as a welcome and overdue development; some understandably saw the plans as a distraction at a time when the partnership’s department stores and Waitrose shops have been crying out for further investment.

But that in itself is something of a sideshow. A much bigger question is what this means for attempts to tackle the country’s long-term housing crisis – not that John Lewis was on the cusp of single-handedly solving the problem, of course.

The company was planning to build 10,000 homes, which isn’t to be sniffed at, but in the context of a severe housing shortage estimated at between 4.3 million and 6.5 million homes, such numbers would have barely scratched the surface.

Nevertheless, the Government should ask itself this: if John Lewis can’t build houses, then isn’t Britain’s broken property market all but doomed? What’s more, how much of a factor was a planning system that has become more onerous – not less – despite repeated pledges from the Treasury to reduce red tape?

After all, it was only in October that the Chancellor promised to scrap “needless form-filling” in an attempt to boost growth. But try telling business leaders, including those leading John Lewis’s housebuilding ambitions, that the infuriating burden of endless regulation, box-ticking and compliance has eased.

John Lewis’s retreat should set off alarm bells among complacent, out-of-touch ministers. It’s not so much that the retailer was uniquely qualified to enter an industry dominated by giants such as Taylor Wimpey, Barratt, Redrow and Persimmon, but more that an organisation of its size and stature has failed because of external forces, including heavy-handed state interference.

As Brendan Geraghty, the chief executive of the Association for Rental Living, puts it, John Lewis “brought something genuinely different to the rental living sector – a trusted consumer brand, a service-first culture and a long-term commitment to quality that institutional investors and residents alike responded to”. On paper, it should have been a winning combination.

Clearly, not all of the obstacles it has faced can be pinned entirely on this Government’s incompetence.

As John Lewis points out, its entry into housebuilding occurred during “a very different financial environment”. Not least “lower borrowing costs” and although interest rates are cooling, they still stand at 3.75pc today compared with 0.1pc at the end of 2021. At current levels, borrowing costs are around 8pc to 9pc higher than they were four years ago, according to Capital Economics.

At the same time, inflation has soared from 0.2pc to 3pc. At 4.4pc as of October 2025, construction cost inflation outstrips the general price increase by a sizeable margin and is projected to rise a further 15pc by the end of the decade.

However, much can be blamed on the dead hand of bureaucracy, including a raft of new safety laws introduced after the Grenfell Tower tragedy that killed 72 people in west London in 2017.

The new framework has led to huge delays. Inquiries by the Building Safety Regulator (BSR), established to regulate buildings of seven or more storeys, have added between 12 and 18 months to project timescales.

Separately, 77pc of new-build applications for these so-called “higher-risk buildings” tabled between late 2023 and early 2025 were rejected, deemed invalid or withdrawn, the BSR’s own data show. That is an astonishing failure rate in a country that built just 139,000 of the 300,000 homes – equivalent to 46pc – it needs to build annually to hit Labour’s target of 1.5 million by 2029.

Industry sources also bemoan a raft of new legislation that has made landlordship less attractive, with the Renters’ Rights Act singled out as particularly burdensome.

Landlords warn that the regulations, scheduled to come into force in May this year, will make it harder to raise capital for new schemes and more difficult to value existing ones.

In December, the House of Lords industry and regulators committee warned: “The scale of the delays caused by the BSR has stretched far beyond the regulator’s statutory timelines for building control decisions.”

Baroness Taylor, the chairman of the committee, called the hold-ups “unacceptable”.

The Renters’ Rights Act is expected to act as an even bigger brake on development.

The new rules are designed to give tenants stronger rights but measures such as the abolition of “no-fault” evictions, limiting rent increases to once per year, the right to challenge any rent rise deemed unreasonable at a tribunal and even the right to keep a pet threaten to tip the scales far too heavily in the other direction.

Landlords understandably fear that the regulation, scheduled to come into force in May this year, will make it more difficult to raise capital for new schemes and harder to value existing ones. Many have reportedly already given up and exited the market.

As Richard Tice, the Reform deputy leader, neatly puts it, it is an example of “well-intentioned legislation that is having the opposite effect”. In other words, classic Labour under Sir Keir Starmer and Rachel Reeves.

Few would argue that the quality of high-rises, in particular, did not need drastic improvement following Grenfell. There are clearly also some rogue landlords out there, from whom vulnerable tenants need protection. But there’s little point in making housing safer if there is nowhere for people to live.

data.title: Fire Biden-linked board member or face ‘consequences’, Trump tells Netflix
data.description:
Donald Trump has demanded that Netflix sack a board member or “pay the consequences” after she warned Democrats would punish companies that “take a knee” to the president.

Susan Rice, who served in both Joe Biden, the former US president, and Barack Obama’s administrations, said companies that had kowtowed to Mr Trump would be “held accountable”, prompting the president to call for her to be fired “immediately”.

The row threatens to jeopardise the streaming giant’s planned $83bn (£60bn) takeover of Warner Bros, which must be approved by US regulators because of competition concerns.

Ms Rice said on a podcast that news organisations and law firms that had gone along with Mr Trump’s demands for loyalty would be “held accountable” if the Democrats returned to power.

She added: “If they think Democrats are going to play by the old rules, they’ve got another thing coming.”

Laura Loomer, an activist and a well-known Trump supporter seen as the standard bearer for the Maga movement, accused Ms Rice of “threatening half of the country with weaponised government and political retribution for choosing who they wanted to vote for as president”.

She added: “This is as anti-American as it gets, and Netflix is proving every day they are an anti-American, WOKE company.”

Responding to that message on Truth Social, Mr Trump said Netflix should fire “Trump Deranged Susan Rice, IMMEDIATELY, or pay the consequences”.

The US president wrote: “She’s got no talent or skills – purely a political hack! HER POWER IS GONE, AND WILL NEVER BE BACK. How much is she being paid, and for what??? Thank you for your attention to this matter.”

Ms Rice rejoined Netflix’s board in 2023 after leaving the Biden administration.

The threat of “consequences” is likely to alarm Ted Sarandos, Netflix co-chief executive, who is in a fiercely contested bidding war with Paramount to buy Warner Bros.

Netflix has reached an agreement with Warner Bros on a combination but the Hollywood studio last week reopened talks with Paramount, which has been stressing the regulatory risks of the Netflix deal.

A merger would need to be approved by US authorities as it would hand Netflix a third of the subscription video-on-demand market, and 23pc of US streaming revenue.

It would also allow the streaming giant to bundle its existing service with Warner Bros’s soon-to-be-launched HBO Max, – a move Netflix said would reduce streaming prices.

It emerged on Saturday that the US department of justice was also investigating whether Netflix wielded anticompetitive leverage when acquiring content.

Mr Trump said the deal could be “a problem” in December and told reporters he would personally be involved in the decision.

However, in a more recent interview with NBC he appeared to backtrack, saying: “I’ve been called by both sides. It’s the two sides, but I’ve decided I shouldn’t be involved. The Justice Department will handle it.”

He added: “There’s a theory that one of the companies is too big and it shouldn’t be allowed to do it, and the other company is saying something else.

“They’re beating the hell out of each other – and there’ll be a winner.”

Paramount is controlled by the billionaire Ellison family, who has close ties to Mr Trump. Meanwhile, Mr Sarandos has sought to court the president over the deal, securing a White House meeting with Mr Trump in the weeks before the deal with Warner Bros was agreed.

Netflix has been approached for comment.

data.title: Soaring household energy debts ‘to hit £7bn by the end of 2026’
data.description:
Britain’s household energy debts will rise from £5.5bn to hit £7bn by the end of the year, a new report has warned.

The increase suggests that at least two million households will struggle to keep up with their gas and electric bills by December 2026, according to a study commissioned by trade body Energy UK.

Persistently high energy bills are largely to blame for the increase in debts, analysts said, although there had also been an uptick in people choosing not to pay.

The increase is problematic not only for those indebted to energy suppliers, but also for other households who have to pay an average surcharge of £50 a year to cover the missing money.

“The household energy debt crisis is spiralling out of control,” the study says. “In the last three years alone, total energy debt and arrears have more than doubled.

“Official figures [from regulator Ofgem] suggest the total now stands at £4.5bn [but] Energy UK’s analysis shows that the true figure is already around £5.5bn.

“Without urgent intervention, the total amount of debt and arrears owed is likely to hit £7bn by the end of the year. This would require a further £10-£15 per year to be added to energy bills.”

Ofgem revealed on Wednesday that annual energy bills will fall by £117 from April as the price cap – the average amount suppliers are allowed to charge their domestic dual-fuel customers – is set at £1,641.

However, bills are still much higher than before the energy crisis, when the price cap was at £1,277.

Energy UK’s report comes amid growing industry concern over rising energy debts and suppliers’ inability to tackle the problem.

Some analysts argue that the surge in debt is partially because of regulations brought in after the British Gas prepayment meter scandal in 2023.

An investigation revealed that debt collection agents working for British Gas were forcibly entering the homes of vulnerable customers to install “pay-as-you-go” prepayment meters, even when those customers had clear medical or financial needs.

Once installed, such meters automatically disconnect energy supplies unless they are topped up. However, the backlash led to such measures being banned.

Britons ‘cannot afford their bills’

Energy UK’s report said: “The reason for such a dramatic increase in energy debt and arrears is that a series of regulatory actions have made it much easier to get into debt, and harder to get out of debt.

“It is striking that no other utility has seen similar increases in debt and arrears.”

Energy UK also highlighted how there were almost one million households for which energy suppliers have no details, making it “extremely difficult to recover unpaid bills in this scenario”.

An Ofgem spokesman acknowledged the problem: “The current levels of energy debt are unsustainable, and this is a challenge that requires action from everyone – the regulator, government, and industry alike.”

Alex Belsham-Harris, head of energy policy at Citizens Advice, added: “We estimate that nearly seven million people are living in households in debt to their supplier.

“Every day our advisers help people who are making impossible decisions between keeping their homes warm to a safe or comfortable level or putting food on the table.”

Simon Francis, coordinator of the End Fuel Poverty Coalition, said: “Energy debt has risen for one simple reason: energy bills have remained far higher than household incomes can sustain.

“This is not a story of widespread ‘on’t pay’ behaviour, it is overwhelmingly about people who simply cannot afford their bills.”

Bill Bullen, chief executive at Utilita Energy, which specialises in supplying energy to lower-income households, said that rising debts would inevitably lead to higher bills for everyone else.

A government spokesman said: “We are working urgently with Ofgem to drive debt out of the energy system and are also delivering reforms that put people first.”

data.title: Miliband deal opens door to Chinese investment in UK wind farms
data.description:
Ed Miliband has opened the door to greater investment by Chinese companies in Britain’s energy infrastructure in a deal that critics say threatens national security.

The Energy Secretary on Friday quietly published the memorandum of understanding he struck with Beijing on his visit to China nearly a year ago, following accusations that he was trying to keep the agreement secret.

It commits the UK to closer cooperation with China on offshore wind farms, electricity grids, battery storage, carbon capture and hydrogen, while leaving the door open to potential cooperation on other areas, including civil nuclear power.

In addition to research and policy exchanges, one section makes clear that both countries will “aim to facilitate opportunities for British and Chinese companies to collaborate to create mutual trade and investment opportunities”, including investments in manufacturing and services.

A spokesman for the Department for Energy Security and Net Zero said the document was not “binding” and that all such deals would be subject to rigorous national security checks.

Labour ‘making us dependent on China’

But the Conservatives claimed Labour’s agreement risked making Britain dependent on Chinese green energy technology that could later be “weaponised” by Beijing.

Claire Coutinho, the shadow energy secretary, said: “The release of Ed Miliband’s secret China deal is a victory for transparency and only comes after months of pressure from the Conservatives.

“Miliband has agreed to ‘cooperate’ on areas where China has complete dominance in global supply chains.”

Ms Coutinho added: “He has stripped out previous commitments to support British industry, and, shockingly, didn’t include a single mention of human rights abuses in Xinjiang or Chinese solar panels being made with slave labour.

“Labour’s net zero targets are making us more dependent on China for our energy supply, just as the world is getting more dangerous.

“We cannot allow our security to be undermined because of ideology.”

‘Wacky conspiracy theories’

Mr Miliband’s deal emerged after months of pushback from the Energy Department, which previously insisted that there was no precedent for publishing deals of this kind.

Officials have pointed to the 2015 deal struck by the Conservatives under David Cameron, who had encouraged a “golden era” of relations between the UK and China.

However, that “dialogue” was later suspended under Theresa May amid growing concerns about the security implications of Chinese involvement in critical infrastructure, with ministers later cancelling China’s involvement in Britain’s nuclear programme as well.

Mr Miliband revived energy cooperation talks with China on his visit last year.

But when pressed to publish the agreement, he accused Ms Coutinho of peddling “wacky conspiracy theories” and refused to say why he would not release the full text 17 times when challenged in a select committee hearing.

Mr Miliband’s new commitment to facilitate investment by Chinese companies in Britain is expected to revive scrutiny of proposals by Mingyang, a Chinese wind turbine manufacturer, to build a £1.5bn factory in Scotland.

That plan is controversial because the Ministry of Defence has reportedly warned that the Chinese could use the turbines as spy sensors or use them as an excuse to send engineers to the UK regularly.

Mingyang has denied that it poses a threat, and there is no suggestion of wrongdoing by the company.

The Government is still considering whether to approve the company’s plans.

Deal ‘in UK’s interests’

On Friday, a spokesman for the Department of Energy Security and Net Zero said Mr Miliband had published the deal to address “inaccurate claims and misinformation”.

The spokesman added: “The 2025 agreement provides a platform to share research and ideas between both countries, and, unlike the 2015 agreement, explicitly excludes co-operation on solar.

“As we have always said, it is in the UK’s interest to engage with the world’s largest emitter and one of our biggest trading partners to tackle the climate crisis and protect the British people.”

Last year, a report by the Royal United Services Institute (Rusi) argued that relying on China to hit Britain’s net zero targets would pose a risk to security.

It warned that dangers risked being “hardwired” into major infrastructure, potentially repeating the mistake Europe made by becoming dependent on Russian gas before the Ukraine war.

data.title: John Lewis abandons plan to build 10,000 homes
data.description:
John Lewis has abandoned plans to build 10,000 homes after struggling with planning red-tape and inflation.

The retailer said it will withdraw from its build-to-rent business, blaming higher interest rates, inflationary pressures and a more cautious property market.

John Lewis said this meant the plan to build and manage flats “no longer meets” its investment criteria, adding: “Our rental property ambition was based on a very different financial environment.”

The partnership had been planning to build three rental home tower blocks under a £500m joint venture with Aberdeen. 

However, it is now planning to sell consents for the schemes – subject to final approvals and following discussions with local authorities – with outside developers expected to be brought in.

It brings an end to John Lewis’s ambitions to ultimately build 10,000 rental homes across the UK.

Britain’s sclerotic planning system is understood to be a major factor in John Lewis’s about-turn. 

Katherine Russell, the director of build-to-rent at the John Lewis Partnership, previously told The Telegraph that “cutting red tape” would speed up investment in new housing and called for Rachel Reeves to introduce tax breaks for developers.

Property experts have complained of delays caused by the Building Safety Regulator, which was introduced following the Grenfell Tower tragedy. Enquiries by the watchdog added between 12 and 18 months to project timescales last year.

Separately, 77pc of new-build applications for so-called “higher-risk buildings” – those over seven storeys high – tabled between late 2023 and early 2025 were rejected, deemed invalid or withdrawn, the BSR’s own data shows.

Industry sources also bemoan a raft of new legislation that has made it less attractive to be a landlord, with the Renters’ Rights Act singled out as particularly burdensome.

The new rules, designed to give tenants stronger rights, include the abolition of “no-fault” evictions, limiting rent increases to once per year, and the right to challenge any rent rise deemed unreasonable at a tribunal.

Landlords warn that the regulations, scheduled to come into force in May this year, will make it harder to raise capital for new schemes and more difficult to to value existing ones.

John Lewis’s decision to exit the housing business marks the latest move to roll back a strategy to diversify its business away from high street retail, championed by Dame Sharon White, its former chairman.

Dame Sharon set a target to make 40pc of profit from areas outside retail, including housing and financial services, by 2030, after she took over as chairman of the John Lewis Partnership in 2020.

However, by March 2024, John Lewis had scrapped that target following years of ballooning losses. At the time, it said it would turn around its business by pursuing a “relentless focus on retail”.

Dame Sharon stepped down as chairman of the partnership in September 2024 and was replaced by Tesco veteran Jason Tarry. He has been spending heavily on revamping tired John Lewis department stores and opening new Waitrose supermarkets, with the company investing £1.8m in stores.

Clive Black, a Shore Capital analyst, said: “John Lewis’s decision to enter the residential property market was noteworthy, not least because at the time the firm was notably struggling as a retailer.

“Under Jason Tarry, sanity is now prevailing, so better and necessary focus upon the core, uplifting what is a premium retail business after all. Encouragingly, Waitrose is showing good signs of progress whilst there is renewed energy around John Lewis, which partners will be hoping augurs well.”

Project setbacks

The partnership had been developing three housing projects, one in Reading and two in London.

In October, John Lewis received planning approval for its rental home scheme in Reading, following earlier approval in West Ealing, in west London, and Bromley, in south-east London.

The projects were part of its £500m, multi-decade joint venture with investment company Aberdeen, aimed at delivering around 1,000 new homes across the three locations.

Abedeen had initially said it would secure £500m from institutional investors for the projects, although that funding was never raised due to the tougher macro-economic conditions.

All three of the schemes faced setbacks, including local opposition to the level of affordable housing in the tower blocks and concerns from NHS officials about the capacity of nearby GP surgeries.

Previous analysis for the rental home schemes, seen by The Telegraph, suggested John Lewis risked spending more on constructing the flats than they would be worth. In 2023, The Telegraph revealed that its West Ealing project was set to deliver a negative return of £57m.

John Lewis argued at the time that it was able to take “a longer-term view”, saying that it wanted to “create as many affordable homes as we can for key workers such as nurses, teachers, the police and care providers”.

John Lewis always maintained that it wanted to “create hundreds of homes at a time; there’s a desperate need for more housing and local investment to support economic growth”.

The retailer is understood to be in talks with local authorities over the change to the schemes. It still needs to finalise consents before it can look at its options for the projects.

John Lewis is also withdrawing from its management of other rental homes. In its build-to-rent business, it manages a number of properties owned by Aberdeen. It said it would fulfil its existing management contracts before handing over to another manager.

data.title: Royal favourite Frog Bikes facing administration
data.description:
A children’s bike-maker favoured by Prince Louis is facing an uncertain future after filing an intention to appoint administrators.

Frog Bikes, founded in 2013 by husband-and-wife team Jerry and Shelley Lawson, made a court application through its law firm Shoosmiths on Friday to hire administrators, legal filings show.

Filing an intention to appoint an administrator is a legal step taken by companies to gain temporary protection from creditors. It can lead to a full-blown liquidation of a company or reorganisation of its finances.

Frog Bikes said the move was a “precautionary measure” to allow the company to keep trading while it explores “potential funding and restructuring solutions”.

Mr Lawson blamed the predicament on a “series of significant and well-documented challenges” – including higher employee taxes, Brexit, and low consumer confidence.

He added, “At the same time, tighter financial markets and reduced access to funding made it increasingly difficult for growing manufacturing businesses to secure the requisite working capital required to navigate these challenges.”

‘Continuing friction’ from Brexit

The Wales-based group has gained a cult following and won a dream endorsement when the Princess of Wales published a photo of her son riding one of the company’s products on his third birthday.

The business makes child-specific bikes after the founders said they struggled to find suitable ones for their own children.

Its lightweight aluminium bikes are made in Pontypool, Wales, where Mr and Mrs Lawson opened a 120,000-square-foot manufacturing facility.

After its success in the UK, it quickly became a market leader for affordable children’s bikes and rapidly expanded to more than 50 countries – including the US and Hong Kong.

However, Frog Bikes has recently warned that cumbersome export taxes were eating into profits.

In 2023, it lost £530,000 after blaming “continuing friction” from Brexit, which had made it harder to compete with European rivals.

However, in its most recent accounts for the year to February 2024, auditors said the group would continue as a going concern.

The report added that despite inflation falling at the time, consumers were still cautious in their spending on “big ticket purchases”, adding that there was competition from new entrants to the lightweight children’s bike market.

Bike market in turmoil

Cycling businesses have faced a difficult time as enthusiasm for the activity starts to wane.

A pandemic boom led many companies to expand rapidly, but after the interest faded, firms complained that the sudden drop in interest had left manufacturers with excess inventory.

Companies like Brompton Bicycles saw profits fall by more than 99pc in the year to March 2024. The following year, it reported pre-tax losses of £2m. At the time, the company described the bike market as being “in turmoil”.

Raleigh, another British brand, reported a loss of £30m in 2023, citing overstocked inventory following the pandemic.

Frog Bikes confirmed in a statement that the search for a new investor would continue.

Mr Lawson said: “All parties are committed to securing a positive outcome for the business, its employees and wider stakeholders.

“Frog Bikes’ priority remains supporting its employees, customers, suppliers, and retail partners while working with its advisers to determine the best possible outcome for all stakeholders.”

data.title: Rolls boss defends request for taxpayer support after handing investors £9bn
data.description:
Rolls-Royce has defended its request for hundreds of millions of pounds of government support as it prepares to hand shareholders up to £9bn.

Tufan Erginbilgic, the company’s chief executive, said on Thursday that state subsidies were needed to help develop the engineering giant’s new engine for narrow-body planes and would be “enormous for the economy”.

The return of Rolls-Royce to narrow-body planes – the kind of short-haul aircraft used by the likes of budget airline Ryanair – was “the single biggest opportunity for a generation” in the UK, he said.

The move has been backed by Labour in the industrial strategy published last year, although it is not yet clear whether ministers have agreed to give Rolls-Royce taxpayer support.

This uncertainty has coincided with German and US officials attempting to persuade Rolls-Royce to outsource some of the development work to suppliers in their countries.

Mr Erginbilgic – dubbed “Turbo Tufan” in the City after reviving Rolls-Royce’s fortunes – refused to speculate on whether a deal with the UK would be reached and insisted it was “not a competition”.

He also defended the request for investment, arguing it was “not uncommon” in the sector and Rolls-Royce would invest far more itself.

He said: “The reason [narrow-body] is the biggest opportunity out there is because it is a $1.6tn (£1.18tn) market – you can create a big supply chain.

“So it’s not only Rolls-Royce; it’s lots of players. You create up to 40,000 jobs, and 80pc of what we do is actually exported.”

The chief executive added: “So you increase exports, you improve economic growth significantly, and our estimation is actually this programme alone will create a gross value of more than £100bn.

“This is actually very good for the UK in terms of job creation and economic growth, and the company – the country – actually needs it.”

His remarks came as Rolls posted a 40pc rise in profits and announced it would return between £7bn and £9bn to shareholders from 2026 to 2028.

Shares initially jumped more than 8pc in early trading, although this later eased to around 4.9pc.

That followed an announcement that the company had exceeded previous turnaround targets set by Mr Erginbilgic, who took over in 2023 and has since led a significant recovery at the British engineering giant.

Rolls-Royce said profits last year leapt from £2.3bn to £3.4bn, after sales rose from £17.8bn to £20.1bn.

The company, which in aviation makes money from the number of “flying hours” its engines operate, is benefiting from the recovery of air travel as well as other major trends such as Western rearmament and the boom in demand for data centres.

Its business spans commercial jet engines, diesel generators and propulsion systems, defence systems (such as fighter jet engines), nuclear submarine reactors and nascent nuclear small modular reactors.

However, Mr Erginbilgic’s turnaround – which came after he warned the company was standing on a “burning platform” in the wake of the pandemic – has involved laying off some 2,500 workers and renegotiating loss-making contracts with airlines.

He said: “We are consistently achieving outcomes that were not possible before our transformation.

“With our new capabilities and mindset, we have navigated challenges from supply chain to tariffs and delivered a strong performance in 2025, all while we built the foundations for significant growth for years to come.”

On Mr Erginbilgic’s bid for support, he added: “This is a programme that the industrial strategy of the UK already identified as the most important programme. It is natural that the Government will look to support that.

“Obviously, we are working with the Government for the right support. But one thing I’m going to say, there are all sorts of numbers out there.”

He added: “Whatever they support, we will appreciate that, but it is going to be a fraction of what we are spending on this programme.

“We have already spent more than a billion pounds, and think about the product development phase, think about the industrialisation phase – you know this industry; we are talking about billions and billions.”

The Government has been approached for comment.

data.title: Daily Mirror owner hammered by Google algorithm changes
data.description:
The publisher of the Mirror and Express newspapers has suffered a plunge in online readership across its regional titles as it reels from Google’s algorithm changes.

Reach saw a sharp drop in page views for dozens of its local titles across the UK last month. Visitor numbers also fell. 

Page views of Surrey Live, one of its properties, tumbled almost 85pc to 4.3 million in January, down from 28.2 million at the same time last year, according to figures from Ipsos.

Leeds Live’s page views dropped by 77pc while Bristol Live tumbled just under 70pc. Reach’s outlets in Lancashire, Plymouth, Gloucestershire and Cambridge all saw their page views fall by more than half.

The number of unique visitors to these outlets also fell in January. A source close to Reach argued that the length of time spent per visit was up 4pc, which they said validated the publisher’s strategy.

‘Very alarming’ decline in reader numbers

Reach has previously blamed tumbling audience numbers on algorithm changes by Google that have caused a “material reduction” in referrals.

Alex DeGroote, a media analyst, described the decline in reader numbers as “very alarming”, adding that it highlighted how the social media age has left many publishers at the mercy of algorithms.

He said: “Unless this is remedied quickly, which seems unlikely, there will be an impact on revenue and profits.”

Reach is scheduled to report its full-year results next week. It has forecast a 1pc fall in digital revenues, with profits ahead of market expectations thanks to cost-cutting measures.

The publisher has largely shunned paywalls in favour of pursuing digital advertising revenue, leaving it heavily reliant on social media platforms such as Facebook and Google to drive traffic.

But recent algorithm changes have taken their toll, particularly as Google has sought to give less prominence to low-quality or recycled content.

Reach has frequently faced accusations of clickbait, as its titles have pursued celebrity news and, for example, stories about the home-furnishings retailer Dunelm over more relevant local reporting.

It also comes amid heavy cutbacks at the publisher that has seen its editorial workforce plunge by around 1,000 in recent years.

Reach said in September it would cut more than 300 jobs, including 186 journalists, in its latest bruising round of redundancies.

At the same time, Reach has ramped up its use of AI. The company has its own generative AI tool – called Guten – which helps journalists quickly rewrite stories “ripped” from rival outlets.

The National Union of Journalists has previously sounded the alarm about the use of the technology, warning that it “jeopardises editorial quality and blurs the distinction between the company’s different brands and regional titles”.

Analysts warned that any increase in AI-generated content would further expose Reach to punishment by Google’s algorithm.

Reach’s woes contrast with growing traffic at rival regional publisher Newsquest, which has kept its local news titles largely independent.

The Ipswich Star and Dorset Echo both recorded an increase in page views of more than 80pc in January, while Scottish title the Herald and Brighton’s the Argus newspaper also grew strongly.

Under Piers North, the chief executive, Reach has sought to centralise more of its editorial resources, while its titles are increasingly focusing on video and audio output rather than text-based stories.

The group has also begun rolling out paywalls for some of its “premium” content to reduce its reliance on digital advertising and generate revenue directly from readers.

Reach also announced it was closing most of its printing presses this month to cut costs.

David Higgerson, Reach’s chief content officer, said: “We’ve been really encouraged by our first six digital subscription launches – take-up has been strong, and we’ll continue to roll these out across our titles.

“As everyone well knows, page views are just one metric, and with the advent of our digital subscriptions strategy, we’re even more focused on our loyal audience, which we have retained.”

Mr Higgerson added: “It is, and always has been, a confection of London’s media elite to suggest we have swapped out local journalism for non-local journalism in our titles – you only have to look at the Manchester Evening News’ extensive range of coverage of the Gorton and Denton by-election for just one of many examples.”

data.title: The Cornish mine that could help Trump in his new arms race with China
data.description:
Britain’s last operational tin mine, South Crofty, has been sitting dormant in Cornwall for nearly 30 years. But now the historic site may be revived thanks to an unlikely benefactor: Donald Trump.

The US president’s administration last week said it was willing to loan up to $225m (£165m) to developer Cornish Metals to support the mine’s reopening – so long as it agrees to send some of the output across the Atlantic.

Just two days earlier, and more than 4,600 miles away, a Washington-backed investment fund had announced a deal to acquire a 40pc share in a copper and cobalt mine run by Glencore in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

And in Western Australia, the US government has emerged as one of the backers of a scheme to build a new refinery that will produce gallium, a rare metal.

The investments follow a spate of dealmaking by the Trump administration at home in the past year – which has seen it take stakes in a magnet producer, a lithium mine and rare earth refineries – among other things.

According to experts, they are all examples of the new, more muscular approach Washington is taking to securing critical minerals abroad as it seeks to break China’s stranglehold over global supplies.

Tin, copper, cobalt and gallium are all commonly used in electronics, while lithium – known as “white gold” – is the main ingredient in batteries that power the modern world.

Rare earth magnets, meanwhile, are found in the spinning parts of wind turbines, electric motors and even fighter plane wing flaps.

Without them, and a plethora of other metals, factory production lines across America would grind to a halt.

That briefly became a real prospect last year, when the US was locked in a trade standoff with China.

“One of the challenges we’ve had in the last 20 years in the United States is our mineral security efforts have largely been contained to handshake diplomacy,” says Gracelin Baskaran, a critical minerals expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS).

“But handshake diplomacy doesn’t bring projects online. And it doesn’t yield minerals that can meet critical security interests.

“It’s the start, but what is the support that we need to get projects into production? It’s financing, it’s trade agreements, it’s off-take agreements [where a customer agrees to buy raw material before it is produced]. That is how we increase access to minerals.

“We’re going from paper agreements to deploying capital.”

US trailing China

This is the thinking behind the dizzying series of deals announced by American officials in recent months.

Efforts to start directly nurturing alternative supplies began under Joe Biden but have accelerated under Trump, with investments made through several arms of the state – including the department of war, the department of energy, the Export-Import Bank of the United States (Exim) and the US International Development Finance Corporation (DFC).

The DFC was the investor that supported Glencore’s copper and cobalt operations, while Exim has extended the offer of loans and financing to the tin project being developed by Cornish Metals.

Yet the Trump administration is still playing catch-up.

Chinese companies have been steadily building their control over key mining and refining operations for decades, giving Beijing the ability to turn off supplies to the rest of the world at will.

Take just one example: copper, the world’s most important industrial metal, used in electrical wiring, circuit boards and plumbing. Analysts predict the world is headed for a supply crunch in the coming years – and China is far better placed to weather it.

The Middle Kingdom’s companies control around 16pc of global copper production compared to 6pc owned by American firms, according to data from Benchmark Mineral Intelligence, and there have been calls in China to boost domestic stockpiles.

“China has been doing this for a while, so this isn’t new for them,” says Albert Mackenzie, an analyst at Benchmark.

“The US may have looked at how they have built up their copper assets overseas, and is now trying to replicate that or not get left behind.

“There’s a big desire for more copper at the moment – you can point at AI, or to the energy transition, but actually it’s in basically everything we use because it’s such a good conductor.”

Minerals monopoly

While China has a grip on supply, its dominance of critical minerals is really about processing, with its share standing at over 50pc for a whole host of metals and exceeding 90pc for certain products.

This means that even though such metals may be mined in the US, Australia or elsewhere, they are still sent to China for refining.

Some 91pc of rare earth magnet metal refining and 94pc of global magnet production is concentrated in China, according to the International Energy Agency.

These are the magnets used in critical parts of the US military’s F-35 stealth fighter, as well as Tomahawk cruise missiles, navy destroyers and submarines, the Stinger portable missile and the M1 Abrams tank.

This leverage was brought into painful focus for Mr Trump last year, when he was forced to walk back his threats of trade tariffs after Beijing imposed export restrictions on heavy rare earths.

Ahead of his visit to China in April, the US president has now approved the creation of a $12bn critical mineral reserve, known as Project Vault, that will seek to guard US manufacturers against similar threats in future.

The initiative has been backed by captains of industry including the bosses of GE Vernova and Boeing.

“We don’t want to ever go through what we went through a year ago,” Mr Trump told reporters last week.

“Just as we have long had a strategic petroleum reserve and a stockpile of critical minerals for national defence, we’re now creating this reserve for American industry, so we don’t have any problems.”

Security and stability

The US administration has also been seeking to rally allies around an international network for developing critical mineral supplies outside of China.

Last week, vice-president JD Vance and Marco Rubio, the secretary of state, hosted a critical minerals summit in Washington aimed at drumming up support for the initiative.

In a speech, Mr Rubio pointed out that the Chinese grip over supplies posed the same danger to all of America’s allies and urged them to work together.

“No country in the world has every critical mineral that’s valuable,” he said. “So it will rely on international cooperation.

“Right now, you have 90-something per cent of some of these elements controlled by one nation, one place. And that’s just not healthy for the global economy and it’s certainly not healthy for security and stability.”

Along with the deals that have been announced, the White House has also vowed to back minerals producers with grants, loans and even “price floors” that will ensure they get paid a minimum amount for their minerals.

This is seen as vital because China’s producers receive large amounts of state support and can otherwise undercut competition from private Western firms.

Dominic Raab, the former Conservative deputy prime minister who now works with minerals investor Appian Capital Advisory, was in the room and says this change in mindset is key.

“There’s a recognition that it’s not a free market, it’s a broken market,” he says. “So they’re going to have to engage at a state level, but they also want to unlock private sector investment, and that’s important for de-risking those investments and unlocking more capital.”

Sophia Gaston, a geopolitics researcher at King’s College London, says the showdown with Beijing last year left Washington officials chastened by America’s “profound vulnerabilities on these supply chains”.

“China called the Trump administration’s bluff, and that forced America back to the negotiation table, and I think they felt extremely exposed by that, and wanted to move quickly to try and prevent that kind of situation happening again,” she says.

“There’s been a very intense flurry of activity, because Donald Trump is pencilled in for a visit to Beijing in April. So I think he wants to feel he’s going into that conversation with the maximum leverage.

“Until that critical minerals and rare earths diversification strategy starts to come into view, that’s going to be difficult – because there will always be a feeling that China can turn off the tap.”

data.title: Bring back the great British TV drama of whisky-swilling businessmen
data.description:
The way we view television has changed enormously in the 73 years since Queen Elizabeth II’s coronation. We’ve gone from flickering black-and-white boxes that took a good 30 seconds to warm up and served up just one channel, to widescreen OLED smart devices that stream thousands of choices of “content” (though, ironically, they still often take a good 30 seconds to start up).

But the actual shows? Although they look very different, the genres of TV drama have stayed remarkably steady over all that time. Flick through the TV listings from any year over the decades, and you will find crime shows, medical shows, soaps, sci-fi, costume drama, historical series, and so on. There’s not all that great a gap between Emergency Ward 10 and Casualty. There’s only one kind of drama series that you will find in a 1966 edition of TV Times that you won’t see while scrolling through your EPG in 2026 (excluding westerns, which were obviously never a British concern anyway). I’m talking about business TV.

There used to be many of these series: The Brothers, The Power Game, The Plane Makers, Mogul, The Troubleshooters. These were gripping stories of men (and it was overwhelmingly men) striding into each others’ offices, pouring whiskies, sparking up cigars, and obsessing over boards, stocks and shares, new products and processes. Women did feature, but until the Eighties they were the wives and secretaries that orbited like satellites around the boardrooms and factory floors where the main events played out.

Now, I will hear you object that boardroom business drama survives – Succession or Industry, for example. The big difference between these modern shows and their forebears is that they aren’t really concerned with the actual business of the business, except where it directly affects the drama between the characters.

Succession didn’t have a storyline about the design of a product – you can’t imagine scenes with Shiv or Roman unfurling plans across a big teak table, or lengthy discussions about the pros and cons of the fuel injection nozzle or whatever. No, Succession is more the inheritor of the Dallas model, the high-glamour soap in which the actual work in hand is merely the convenient backdrop.

The true business TV drama of old portrayed the actual business as dramatic in itself. The heyday of the form was 1963’s The Plane Makers, the story of an aviation design firm which after three series reinvented itself in 1965 as The Power Game, shifting its anti-hero John Wilder (Patrick Wymark) to a merchant bank. The tensions of manufacture, negotiations and industrial relations were depicted in detail that seems baffling today.

There is a sense of great public interest in business in other shows of the time. Early Honor Blackman episodes of The Avengers feature Steed and Mrs Gale investigating chicanery at works making pottery and optical lenses, and trying to expose export licences for counterfeit packaging. It’s all very unusual to 21st-century eyes.

The Wymark model – the tycoon stomping about, all blood and thunder, in his executive suite – became such an established part of TV that Fry and Laurie would spoof it in their John and Peter sketches: “Damn it to damnation, triple blast, John, I want to know what the hell is going on!”

The sometimes strained and phoney scene-setting dialogue of the genre – as we pick up the characters before the meat of the scene – was also brilliantly lampooned by Victoria Wood, who opens a visit to Acorn Antiques with Miss Babs pointing at blank sheets of paper and telling Miss Berta, “Yes, that’s much better – if we deliver these antiques on Friday morning, we can take delivery of these antiques in the afternoon.”

By the Seventies, the genre had become so established that it started generating oddities of its own. Hine, from 1971, is a fascinatingly weird one-off, created by Power Game writer Wilfred Greatorex (what a fantastic “Dammit, Marjorie!” name that is).

Hine starred the personable Barrie Ingham as the titular hero, who is a freelance international arms dealer. Viewers were baffled – were we really meant to be rooting for this charming chap in his attempts to sell British weapons to dictatorships in the Middle East? – and the show flopped. It stands now as a fascinatingly amoral glimpse into a hidden world.

The episode “The Old School Noose” by Arden Winch (another great moniker and nothing to do with the workwear firm of the same name), in which Hine is caught in an elaborate web involving his childhood best friend who is now a Labour MP, is one of those exquisite pieces of dramatic writing and acting that occasionally startles you in a vintage “hack-for-hire” series.

So what became of the “pure” business drama? The last British example I can think of that still retained elements of it was Eighties super-soap Howards’ Way, the BBC’s answer to Dynasty. Much of the action in its initial stages revolved around the design and production of a new racing boat, and the dilemma between using hand-crafted or machine-made mouldings. Try pitching that to Netflix. But fairly soon this faded into the background, swallowed up by the ins and outs of Relton Marine, Leisurecruise, the House of Howard, and which character owned what percentage of them.

In fact, in the Nineties, business started infecting our less glam soaps. When I worked as a writer on Coronation Street, Fiona Middleton – aged 21! – owned the salon, while Brookside’s teenage entrepreneur Jacqui Dixon had fingers in investment pies everywhere, and in EastEnders Sharon Watts became Walford’s answer to Howard Hughes. These may have been intended as inspiring messages of female empowerment, but they were both highly unlikely and difficult for viewers to identify with.

The simple answer to the mystery of business TV’s decline is that Britain stopped manufacturing things. There are currently politicians on all sides mooting the return of long-defunct industries to our land. In the unlikely event that they succeed, perhaps once again viewers will see people slamming down tumblers of Scotch and bellowing at their secretaries, damn it!

data.title: The British-designed microchip that is powering Putin’s deadly missiles
data.description:
Yana Khudyo, 15, woke to find herself trapped and buried beneath the rubble of her home.

Two of her ribs and one leg had been shattered by an explosion.

It took rescuers 40 minutes to pull her from the wreckage after Igor, her 24-year-old brother, heard her calling beneath the debris.

Viktoria and Oleg, their parents, and Danylo, their 17-year-old brother, were already dead. It took rescuers another 18 hours to find their bodies, and for Igor to identify them.

What ripped the Khudyo family apart on April 24, 2025, was a KN-23 ballistic missile. And, at the heart of that tragedy, helping power the missile, there may have been a British microchip.

Fired by Russia, it struck a residential block in Kyiv’s Sviatoshynskyi district, murdering twelve Ukrainians as they slept.

After the attack, Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukrainian president, said the weapon responsible for orphaning Yana contained 116 Western-made components.

Little additional detail was given.

The type of North Korean missile used in the strike has been found to contain British-made converters, according to Ukrainian investigators. 

It is one of thousands of Russian weapons that use Western – including British – dual-use military-grade components. Dual-use devices have both military and civilian use, meaning they can be used as easily in a computer as in a missile.

When Igor arrived at the site of the devastation, about 20 minutes after the strike, he saw his childhood home in smithereens.  

“I started desperately calling out to my mother, my father, to Daniel and to Yana,” he said from his apartment just outside Kyiv. 

“The mobile phones of the dead were ringing, but no one was picking up,” he continued as we sat in darkness caused by Russian air strikes.

“I tried to call Yana and when I heard her pick up the phone I knew she was alive. But there was no sound.

“She sent me a text which said ‘I am under rubble, I am dying’ and her rough location.

“I started frantically searching, despite Shahed drones circling overhead, until finally I heard her calling out to me from beneath the destruction.”

Yana had been thrown from her bed and trapped under a cupboard. 

She was operated on twice. “I found out my parents had died on Instagram while I was in the hospital,” she said.

“The psychologist was meant to tell me, but it was all over social media by the time I woke up from my surgeries.”

The impact of this experience on her is clear.

“I want to join the military [when I am 18],” she said proudly.

“This is the only future I see for myself because I want to be part of the people fighting for their land and their parents. I want to become a hero for Ukraine.”

With 16,000 international trading restrictions in place in Russia, how could British-made parts have found their way into Russia’s deadly arsenal, and why are sanctions not working?

The Telegraph and the Committee for Freedom in Hong Kong Foundation (CFHK), a human rights watchdog, are exposing how middlemen in Hong Kong have shipped thousands of dual-use components worth millions of dollars from Western Europe to Russia.

Campaigners want the Government to open an urgent “investigation” into how British parts reportedly ended up in weapons used against Ukraine, and to “close any loopholes” around pre-existing laws.

On Sept 7, 2024, a North Korean KN-23/24 ballistic missile with the serial number 312518759 was shot down in the villages of Myrne and Bilyky, Poltava Oblast, Ukraine.

It was one of 60 KN-23 or Hwasong 11A missiles supplied to Putin by Kim Jong-un and launched that year.

Buried among the rubble and shrapnel, investigators said they found two products labeled as coming from the British company XP Power: a DC/DC converter and a power converter.

Converters transfer direct currents from one voltage level to another and are commonly used to stabilise, boost, or lower a voltage within a machine.

XP Power, which has headquarters in Reading, Berks, said converters allegedly found in Russian weapons were either counterfeit or “sold before the invasion”. The firm has not provided any additional detail or evidence to support these assertations.

Both chips recovered in the rubble were allegedly manufactured in 2023, a year after the Kremlin’s invasion of Ukraine, and after XP Power said it had ceased trading with Russia.  

Russian customs data from 2022-2024, obtained by CFHK and reviewed by The Telegraph, found that 799 XP Power-labelled cargoes valued at around $2.5m (£1.8m) had been imported by Russia. It is not clear how XP Power-labelled devices ended up in North Korea. 

It is unknown where exactly the missiles containing the XP Power-branded converters were made in North Korea. The country expanded its missile production capactity in 2024. The Ryongsong Machine Complex in the Hamhung region is a key factory where these weapons are built.

The CFHK figures, which come from tracking the sale and shipments of high-risk goods to sanctioned countries, suggest almost half were sent via Hong Kong to electronic supply companies Woeroon Electronic Sourcing Limited, SSP LTS and Imaxchip. None of these companies responded to requests for comment.

It is not clear if these companies were seeking to breach sanctions, or if they were aware these shipments might be used by the Russian military.

XP Power disputed CFHK's findings, stating that “all orders from customers and shipments to customers are thoroughly checked for sanctioned countries and companies”.

The company said it had “never traded” directly with Woeroon, SSP LTS, Imaxchip or any of the companies named in the shipment data.

There is no suggestion that XP had any knowledge of where its components would end up, and no evidence the company was complicit in sending parts to Ukraine.

But it is common for middleman businesses committing sanctions evasion to pass dual-use stock from company to company.

“Naturally, we have less visibility of sales that might pass through a number of hands in the supply chain,” a spokesman for XP Power accepted.

She added: “We have stringent export controls in place and take our responsibilities under the various sanction regimes very seriously – after the invasion in February 2022, we immediately stopped all shipments to Russia.  

“We take our obligations in this area very seriously and we will continue to work with others in the supply chain to ensure their controls are as tight as ours.

“All of our sales contracts now include clauses to specifically prohibit onward sale or re-exporting to Russia.”

It is not just the KN-23 missile that has been found to contain British-made hardware.

British components have also been found in deadly Shahed drones, First-Person View drones, guided missiles and scores of other weapons launched by the Russian military into Ukraine.

In total, Ukrainian investigators have found 41 British-made components on the battlefield since the start of the war in 2022.  

On Dec 1 last year, the Ukrainian military downed a newly modified Geran-2 or Shahed attack drone carrying an R-60 infrared guided AAM (Air-to-Air Missile) on a top-mounted rail launcher.

On Jan 12 2026, Ukraine brought down a Geran-2 or Shahed UAV with Verba MPADS (man-portable air defence system).

In both cases, investigators said they found a British-made Raspberry Pi microcomputer in the drone.

When contacted, Raspberry Pi said it was aware that its products had been “diverted through third-party supply chains” and used in Russian drones.

The tech firm said that “diversion can occur via complex and opaque chains of onward sale in jurisdictions where visibility is limited”.

A spokesman for the company added: “Raspberry Pi complies fully with all applicable UK, EU and international sanctions regimes and operates controls designed to track and prevent diversion to Russia or the Russian defence sector.

“The company does not disclose the detailed mechanics of its anti-diversion processes.”

Campaigners said this was not good enough.

Samuel Bickett, a former political prisoner in Hong Kong and co-author of CFHK’s report, said: “British manufacturers of components used in Russian weapons are not doing enough to control the flow of these goods across the world.

TT Electronics in Woking, Surrey, looks like any other grey, industrial manufacturing business.

According to its website, it makes advanced electronics for “aerospace, defence, healthcare, automation and electrification”.

It has 19 manufacturing sites across Britain, China, North America and Thailand.

Ukrainian investigators say they have found 11 transistors manufactured by TT Electronics in automated radio jammers and transmitter interference devices used by the Russians on the battlefield.

Between 2022 and 2024, documents reviewed by CFHK suggest that Russia received 59 imports of TT Electronics-labelled components with a declared value of $1.2m. Around 40 per cent of these shipments, worth $700,000, went via Hong Kong.

Hong Kong has become an increasingly important hub for sanctions evasion used by foreign governments seeking to dodge Western embargoes. 

The TT Electronics shipments were imported by four Hong Kong-based traders and logistics firms, including companies associated with the electronics supplier Woeroon. 

Woeroon, which made 25,707 shipments to Russia between 2022 and 2024, is a collective of several unrelated companies. 

Sir Iain Duncan Smith, co-chairman of the Interparliamentary Alliance on China, said: “This Government is turning out to be a lapdog to China.

“It is China and the CCP-controlled Hong Kong that is allowing dual-use components into Russia.

“Sanction evasion has been going on for a while and it is absolutely wrong for the government to turn a blind eye to it.

“The British Government doesn’t seem to care when the sanctions we are meant to be imposing are not being enforced at all. It is an absolute disgrace.

“And the result is that Russia can continue fighting its brutal war of invasion.”

Golledge Electronics, headquartered in Basingstoke, also has products which appear to have been used by Russia.

The company’s “frequency control products” are said by investigators to have been repeatedly discovered inside sophisticated Russian weaponry, including the Tornado C guided missile, the 9M727 cruise missile and the Kh-47M2 Kinzhal missile.

Since Putin’s invasion in 2022, Ukrainian government investigators say they have discovered eight Golledge-labelled components in Russian weapons. Most recently, a Quartz oscillator was found in a cruise missile on Oct 25 2025.

Between 2022 and 2024, Russia received 114 Golledge Electronics-labelled shipments, 30 of which came via six Hong Kong-based companies, including Woeroon and Asialink Shanghai International Logistics Co Ltd, according to analysis by CFHK.

Asialink, a cargo transportation service which has an official partnership with Russia’s national airline Aeroflot, supplied 3,700 high-risk goods worth $6.3m to Russia from March 2022 to January 2024, according to CFHK. It even used Russian as the default language for its website in 2023. 

While the US has already sanctioned Asialink for continued shipments to businesses in Russia, the EU and UK have not.

TT Electronics and Golledge Electronics were contacted for comment.

There is no suggestion that any of the British companies named are deliberately selling their products to Russia.

Bill Browder – the American-born businessman, author and head of the Global Magnitsky Justice campaign – said: “It’s outrageous that British components would have found their way into Russian weapons. 

“This is exactly what the UK sanctions were supposed to prevent. 

“I hope that we figure out how these components found their way into these weapons so sanctions can be tightened.

“Innocent people in Ukraine have died because of these weapons being used on them and we need to get to the bottom of this.”

Chloe Cheung, a Hong Kong dissident who has a China-issued 1,000,000 HK dollar (£100,000) bounty on her head, co-wrote the CFHK report. She said: “It’s shocking that the city I grew up in is now linked to illegal weapons trade rather than to the values of integrity and accountability that once defined it.

“Hong Kong is funnelling components into Russia’s war machine. Our city is indirectly contributing to the killing of Ukrainians. This is the result of Chinese Communist Party control.

“A city once known for rule of law and clean governance, which claims to be an international financial hub, has instead become a haven for dirty money and illegal traders, barely recognisable as the place I once called home.”

Lord Austin, vice-chairman of the Magnitsky Sanctions and Reparation all-party parliamentary group, said: “It would be completely unacceptable if British components are fuelling Russia’s war machine.

“Ministers must take immediate steps to close any sanctions loopholes.”

Mr Bickett, the CFHK report's co-author, added: “It is critical that Britain work with allies to create a genuine multilateral authority with the power to institute sanctions quickly and broadly against all Russian and non-Russian parties involved in evading export controls.”

Responding to our findings, a government spokesman said: “We take reports of goods from UK companies being found in Russian weaponry incredibly seriously.

“We have banned the export of thousands of goods to Russia, including every battlefield item Ukraine has brought to our attention, and together with our international partners have implemented the most severe package of sanctions ever imposed on a major economy.

“Non-compliance with sanctions is a serious offence punishable through large financial penalties or criminal prosecution.”

Konstantin Bychek, 36, was standing by his kitchen window when a North Korean KN-23 struck the neighbouring apartment block on April 24, 2025.

“The shock wave threw me against the wall,” he said while standing in the remains of his old home, almost a year after the deadly strike.

“My face and neck were shredded by shards of glass, and I was drenched in blood.

“I shut my eyes, but behind my eyelids I could see a blinding orange flash [from] when the explosion happened.”

Natalia, his wife, who also survived the explosion, said Europe should crack down on sanctions evasion. “We would like all possible supplies to Russia to be cut off,” she said.

“I don't understand how this can happen, given that Russia is under sanctions.”

Igor, who is now his sister Yana’s legal guardian, warned: “Western Europe should not forget what is going on in Ukraine.

“If Europe doesn't help us now, you will see the same in your countries.”

As we approach the fourth anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, we must ask ourselves: why is Europe still shooting itself?
