data.title: Reeves abandons decision to block £1bn defence deal after backlash
data.description:
Rachel Reeves has about-turned on her refusal to sign off on a long-delayed £1bn military helicopters contract after being warned it would cost thousands of British jobs.

The Chancellor and her officials made a hasty reversal on funding for the £1bn new medium helicopters (NMH) programme on Friday as sources claimed she was committed to “keeping the country safe.”

Just hours earlier, the Telegraph had revealed that Treasury officials had bluntly told the Ministry of Defence they would not approve a contract for defence giant Leonardo until the MoD’s wider equipment plans were settled.

That would have put 3,000 jobs at risk in Leonardo’s factory in Yeovil, Somerset.

But Treasury officials have now let it be known that the Chancellor will approve the deal – and blamed the MoD for the holdups, claiming defence officials had “deprioritised” the NMH programme.

“Rachel cares about keeping the country safe and driving jobs in the UK because our security and economic growth are fundamentally connected,” one official told the Financial Times.

Defence sources said they did not recognise the Treasury’s claims and insisted NMH capability was part of their equipment plans.

Senior figures involved in the discussions had warned earlier in the day that Ms Reeves’s initial refusal to approve the deal risked “biblical” job losses.

Another source said Downing Street and the MoD had both been supportive of the deal but that the Treasury was “saying no”.

One Whitehall source told the Telegraph Ms Reeves’s about-turn was a “face-saving exercise.”

Leonardo declined to comment.

Yeovil is the last factory in the country capable of designing and manufacturing helicopters from start to finish, but has not won a UK government contract in more than a decade.

Leonardo executives have repeatedly warned that it would be at risk unless it secured the NMH work.

The Yeovil plant is the former home of Westland Helicopters, later known as AgustaWestland, which merged with Leonardo in 2016.

In the 1980s, members of the Thatcher government disagreed bitterly over whether Westland should be rescued by an American or European firm.

The row led to the resignations of Lord Heseltine, the defence secretary at the time, and Leon Brittan, the trade secretary. It also exposed displeasure within the Conservative Party about Margaret Thatcher’s leadership style, sowing the seeds of her eventual downfall in 1990.

Senior bosses from the company had travelled in secret to Yeovil on Thursday for an expected announcement of the deal by John Healey, the Defence Secretary, only to be told at short notice that the visit was off.

The Treasury’s decision to block the contract award was initially understood to be linked to the delayed defence investment plan (DIP), a blueprint that is supposed to set out what equipment the military will purchase over the next decade.

Ministers previously promised to publish the document before the end of last year but it has yet to emerge amid reports of a £28bn funding shortfall.

The Telegraph revealed earlier this month that Ms Reeves, the Chancellor, was refusing to sign off more money and had told the MoD that it must stick within spending plans agreed last year.

The MoD said it was “working flat out” to finalise the DIP, which would “deliver the best kit and technology into the hands of our frontline forces at speed, while investing in and growing the UK economy”.

The NMH tender process has already dragged on for years and Italy’s Leonardo is the sole remaining bidder after rivals dropped out.

That had led to increasingly stark warnings from Leonardo executives about the stakes if the company did not secure the work.

On top of some 3,000 jobs at Yeovil they have warned that the total number of workers reliant on the plant is around 10,000 when supply chains are included.

In a letter first reported by The Telegraph, Leonardo group boss Roberto Cingolani warned Mr Healey that the Italian giant could scrap all investment in Britain if the deal didn’t go ahead.

Luke Pollard, the defence procurement minister, vowed earlier this month that the Government would not let the company’s offer “time out” on Sunday.

But defence industry sources were warning earlier on Friday that it looked as though the deal would fall through.

That would have piled more pressure on Ms Reeves.

James Cartlidge, the shadow defence secretary, said: “If Labour scraps the New Medium Helicopter programme, it will be a disaster for the factory at Yeovil and the UK’s sovereign military rotary capability.

“Above all, it would be a disaster for thousands of skilled workers in the South West and right across the UK, the supply chain, whose jobs rely on the site.

“Rachel Reeves has banged on about how defence is an ‘engine for growth’, but in reality her total failure to put money into defence is destroying a once-great industry.”

Union pressure

Sharon Graham, general secretary of the Unite union, a major Labour donor, had said that the Chancellor should step aside if she was not prepared to approve the NMH deal.

She said on Friday: “The Leonardo contract is a tremendous victory for Unite members in Yeovil and across the aerospace sector. 

“Without their commitment, hard work and dedication, it would not be being signed today.
 
“Of course, we are pleased that the Rachel Reeves has now listened to Unite on this issue. 

“However, it took way too long to get this done, and we still have to question why workers were left in the dark until the 11th hour.”

The Treasury did not respond directly to requests for comment, with a spokesman referring The Telegraph to the MoD.

The last major contract awarded to Leonardo’s Yeovil site was for the construction of around 60 Wildcat helicopters for the Army and the Royal Navy in 2006.

Since then Yeovil has secured various export orders to countries including South Korea, Japan and Oman, which helped to sustain the plant’s workforce, but this work is about to end.

Executives have been counting on the new NMH contract to provide further work as well as the impetus for fresh investment into the historic site, where Spitfires were once produced during the Second World War.

The NMH programme was meant to provide a replacement for the Royal Air Force’s ageing Puma battlefield helicopters, a workforce fleet used for a range of duties, which were retired earlier this year.

A 2022 contract advertised by the MoD said up to 44 new aircraft would be sought but that number has since been slashed to 25.

data.title: France cashes in on Britain’s net zero blitz through £10bn deal
data.description:
To understand why Paris-based utility company Engie surprised the market with a late-night deal to buy one of Britain’s biggest power networks, consider two words: net zero.

Catherine MacGregor, the chief executive of Engie, said in a statement late on Wednesday confirming the £10.5bn takeover of UK Power Networks (UKPN) that the deal would help the French company to become “the best energy transition utility”.

Transition is the industry term for shifting to electric – and it is not hard to see why UKPN appeals.

The company is a crucial part of Britain’s power system that runs the entire electricity distribution network for London and the South East of England.

“We are very excited to be part of this adventure,” MacGregor said on Thursday. She said the goal was “making sure that we can accompany the UK in its ambitions for growth and its clean power 2030 target”.

The responsibility may be huge but so too are the potential profits. UKPN is the monopoly owner of cables carrying power to 19 million people.

Geographically, it serves people ranging from Cromer on Norfolk’s north coast to Brighton on the south coast and everything in between.

Its job is to take electricity from National Grid’s high-voltage lines, reduce the voltage and then feed it into 8.5 million homes and businesses. The average domestic customer had £113 added to their bill for those services last year – an amount set to rise sharply over the next five years of planned upgrades.

UKPN also supplied about 71 terawatt hours of power last year – 28pc of the UK total – via its 45,000km of overhead lines and 147,000km of underground cables.

But it is the numbers on the balance sheet that likely appealed most to Engie.

Electricity distribution networks are geographic monopolies so their charges and profits are overseen by government regulator Ofgem, which is meant to keep them under control.

However, the regulator has come under fire for allowing companies such as UKPN to make what critics claim is excessive profit.

A recent report from consultancy Ibis World suggested that the six companies operating the UK’s 15 regional power distribution networks were set to make profit margins of up to 81pc this year. The industry says it needs large margins because it has to make substantial capital investments.

Still, the sector is certainly doing well.

UKPN’s last published accounts for 2024-25 showed its turnover surged to £2.5bn, up from £1.8bn the year before. It produced earnings before tax and depreciation of £1.8bn while post-tax profits rose from £540m to £853m.

“We have a legally binding commitment [to the UK] to help achieve net zero by 2050 that means heat has got to be electrified and transport needs to be electrified,” says Basil Scarsella, the chief executive of UKPN.

“The forecasts suggest if that happens then peak demand would at least double and if it doubles, we need to reinforce – significantly reinforce – the network to make sure that we don’t get in the way of the transition. We are going to do that.”

As a result, the company is pledging £1.5bn a year of new investment for the next few years, with funds expected to increase after that. The cost of those upgrades will filter through into bills.

Yet, this is not the only reason why the deal has attracted attention.

The sale of UKPN will also see a crucial piece of UK infrastructure fall largely under the control of France with a board dominated by the country’s economics ministry, which holds 40pc of Engie’s voting rights.

It tightens France’s grip on British electricity systems, following years where it has been building up its UK assets.

The same ministry oversees EDF, France’s state-owned energy generator, which runs all of the UK’s nuclear power stations and is currently building two more at Hinkley in Somerset and Sizewell in Suffolk.

Dale Vince, the founder of Ecotricity, says this continues a trend which has been happening for some time.

“We gave up energy sovereignty a long time ago when the Conservatives sold off our networks and supply companies,” he says.

“So the French may have a bigger stake in our networks but National Grid is listed on the New York stock market and our water companies are mostly owned from tax havens. This is the legacy of 1990s Conservative privatisations.

“Failing national infrastructure, starved of investment but pumping out billions in dividends to foreign shareholders and simply not serving our national needs.”

So should Britain be more worried about handing over more of its energy sovereignty to France?

MacGregor says not: “We are in the business of running regulated assets, which are subjected to very focused national regulation. And that’s what we do all the time.”

She says the French government is “very far from having that type of influence”.

She added: “With UKPN, we will be respecting the governance of UKPN as a UK regulated entity but also, of course, doing what Ofgem [the UK regulator] and our different stakeholders expect us to do.”

‘UKPN is no longer owned’ by China

Others claim there is, in fact, reason to welcome Engie’s takeover. Until this week, UKPN was owned by Hong Kong billionaire Sir Li Ka-shing’s CK Infrastructure Holdings – a company with close links to the Chinese government.

That position may have seemed acceptable back in 2010 when CK bought UKPN from EDF – then its owner – but the growing tension in UK-China relationships has since caused increasing concern amongst UK ministers.

Richard Tice, the Reform Party’s energy spokesman, says that the deal is good news for Britain on balance because it removes any Chinese control from the system.

“I’m delighted that UKPN is no longer owned by a Chinese corporation in hock to the Chinese government,” he says.

“I suspect the Chinese can see the writing on the wall. The pressure is growing for their control of key UK assets to come to an end and the French are our friends.”

While many would agree with Tice’s sentiment, Ofgem’s latest annual report into the UK’s power distribution networks may offer a different perspective.

In the regulator’s rankings of the best-performing power networks, UKPN has consistently ranked at or near the top.

Its results last year were so good that Ofgem allowed it a performance bonus of £44m – higher than any other company – including £8.5m for customer satisfaction alone.

Simon Gallagher, a grid expert, says this has not always been the case.

Gallagher, who now acts as managing director of UK Network Services, a company specialising in helping businesses get grid connections, was formerly a senior manager with UKPN under both its previous owners.

“Before EDF’s takeover in 2010, it was one of the worst performing distribution companies for customer services and for power cuts. Under China’s CK Infrastructure, it was transformed into one of the best,” he says.

Still, he says this is “not because of Chinese ownership”.

“It is because the Chinese largely left it alone and because it has a good leadership team. The big question is whether Engie will do the same,” he says.

“History suggests that when specialist companies like UKPN are absorbed into a larger company, they tend to be compromised and performance goes off a cliff.”

It may be a risk but it is one that bosses at Engie have been quick to note.

On Wednesday night, they said they stood ready to continue UKPN’s strong performance.

“We have every intention to make sure UK Power Networks remains a top notch operator here in the UK,” MacGregor said.

If it succeeds, the rewards will be significant.

data.title: Train driver who fell asleep at controls drops attempt to overturn sacking
data.description:
A train driver who fell asleep at the controls has abandoned a trade union-backed attempt to overturn his sacking.

The unnamed Hull Trains driver was dismissed a year ago after experiencing “fatigue” at the controls of the company’s 125mph services on several occasions, The Telegraph previously disclosed.

These came to light when he mentioned them in passing during a work meeting, having previously been helped through similar health-related problems by Hull Trains’ managers.

Trade union Aslef called almost a full year of strikes to try to reverse the sacking but admitted defeat on Friday, with the former driver accepting he would not be reinstated.

The series of ineffectual Aslef strikes led to union membership among Hull Trains’ drivers dropping by more than a third during the past year, The Telegraph understands.

Fewer and fewer drivers were keeping up their Aslef membership, which averaged £373 per year in 2024, even as the union claimed that its members were repeatedly voting in favour of walkouts.

In a letter from last March explaining the driver’s dismissal, Martijn Gilbert, Hull Trains’ managing director, said: “The disclosures made by this driver ... presented us with a safety risk that we could not ignore.”

It continued: “We cannot be confident that they can be trusted to properly report safety matters ... so that we can support them and manage the risk.”

Under Mick Whelan, its previous general secretary, Aslef claimed Hull Trains was spreading “false and inaccurate” information.

Aslef and other unions claimed victory over the Conservative government in 2024 in a long-running row about anti-union laws designed to limit strikes’ ability to halt rail services.

Labour has repealed that law – the Minimum Service Levels Act 2023 – as part of pro-union reforms designed to boost membership numbers within such organisations, which in turn channel some of their members’ subscriptions into the political party’s funds.

Aslef failed to respond to a request for comment.

A spokesman for Hull Trains said: “We are pleased that our customers can continue to travel with confidence when booking with Hull Trains, following the positive outcome of our talks with Aslef.

“The safety of our customers and colleagues has and always will continue to be our number one priority.

“We look forward to welcoming record numbers of customers onboard in 2026 after achieving best long-distance train operator in the rail customer experience survey published in December.”

data.title: ‘It’s idyllic’: The jobs that come with their own home
data.description:
With housing costs now the single biggest strain on finances, workers are hunting for a radical solution. And some are finding it through a hidden gem in the employment market – the “tied accommodation” role.

From chefs and gardeners to teachers and animal carers, professionals are increasingly seeking positions that offer refuge from the relentless climb of housing costs.

The figures are stark. The average weekly mortgage payment has soared to £242, according to the Government’s latest English Housing Survey, up from £182 just five years ago. For renters, the outlook is even more grim, with Zoopla reporting average monthly rents of £1,320, outstripping typical mortgage payments.

In this landscape, a job that includes a home is not a mere perk – it’s a life-changing financial reprieve.

‘Job with a house’

Vicki Alford, 47, horse unit manager at Blue Cross rehoming centre in Burford, agrees. For two decades, her role caring for over 60 rescued horses on-site – and overseeing nearly 500 more at properties nationwide – has come with a home.

She started in a flat and later moved to a three-bedroom bungalow with a large garden to accommodate her growing family. Managing a 120-acre site where horses often arrive in desperate need of veterinary and behavioural care is a round-the-clock labour of love. “Every month, around 20 to 30 need retraining,” she explains.

Alford’s need for an on-site house was proven one memorable night when 15 mares foaled simultaneously. “I was the only one on duty, so I helped with the births until the vet arrived,” she says.

Her family has also benefitted from the lifestyle that comes with the job. Alford’s two children grew up surrounded by horses, and freedom from a mortgage or rent has allowed her to save substantially.

While her part-time salary might be modest – the full-time equivalent is paid up to £35,436 – having a cost-free home has paid off. The arrangement has enabled her to save for a house, which she now rents out, securing her financial future.

‘I do pay rent, but it’s subsidised’

It’s a similar story for Louise Ellis, head gardener at English Heritage’s Audley End House and Gardens in Saffron Walden.

“I’ve lived and worked here for 17 years. I started out as a trainee gardener on the minimum wage after a career change from social care and gained my horticultural qualification,” she explains.

Now in charge of 13 paid staff and around 65 volunteers, Ellis oversees the landscaped parkland and the Victorian kitchen garden, which includes a vinery dating back to the 1820s. What she particularly loves about her role is that, while she has climbed to a managerial position, she still does much of the hands-on gardening.

She lives in Orchard Cottage, which is one of the original Victorian staff houses. The one-storey, two-bedroom home has character features including a vaulted ceiling, along with a modern extension containing the bedrooms and a bathroom. Ellis lives alone as her partner is based in Norfolk.

“It’s very well-maintained and sits within the unrestored parts of the walled garden. I also have my own private garden with fruit trees,” she says. Ironically, there is a large, detached red-brick home called the Head Gardener’s House, but that is now let out to paying holiday guests.

There are four staff members who live on site, including the stable manager and other gardeners. “The provision of housing is an allowance for our out-of-hours responsibilities. We must respond quickly if there is an emergency, which requires us to live on site,” she says.

“I do pay rent, but it’s subsidised. It has enabled me to save a quarter of my salary every month, something I’ve been very focused on now that I am 55 and retirement is on the horizon. I’ll need to work until I reach the state pension age, but my job keeps me physically fit, so that’s a benefit,” she says.

She is aware that she lives in an expensive market town, where a two-bedroom home costs on average £1,359 per month. “I wouldn’t be able to live here on my salary if I had to rent privately. I’d probably need to move further out towards Suffolk to afford a similar home,” she says.

“English Heritage is a great landlord. It deals with repairs promptly and is progressive – we have oil central heating, but it is looking at air-source heat pumps and alternative fuel sources,” she says. 

Ellis doesn’t own a property elsewhere and knows that when she retires from Audley End, she will be back to paying for a home in the private rental sector.

‘It’s idyllic’

Hospitality, with its long and sometimes anti-social hours, is another industry that frequently offers staff accommodation – particularly in remotely located hotels.

Billy McKechnie, 45, is general manager of the Royal Marine Hotel in Brora, located an hour’s drive from Inverness along the North Coast 500.

He has been in the role for three and a half years. Part of his daily duties include playing the bagpipes to welcome guests to breakfast. Along with his wife Minette and their three children, he is provided with accommodation.

“Our children play in the hills or at the beach, visit neighbouring castles and play golf in their free time – it’s idyllic,” says McKechnie.

Lifestyle aside, the perk of staff accommodation is a definite help for the family’s purse strings. “The hotel contributes towards the rent on our house, which is £1,200 per month. We chose the house ourselves. It’s five minutes by car from the hotel.”

In an area that is losing residents to nearby cities, providing hotel staff with subsidised housing is a key incentive for securing their commitment.

“We have a house in Inverness that we rent out. We wouldn’t have moved from there if the hotel didn’t provide us with a home,” he says. Plus, if the family had sold their main home to buy closer to McKechnie’s workplace, they would have faced both seller’s fees and stamp duty costs.

For younger workers, having accommodation provided allows them to go where the jobs are.

James Greenwood-Penny, 24, is the sous chef at The Cottage in the Wood in Malvern. “I was born and grew up in Cornwall – a long way from Malvern,” he says.

He notes that without the housing perk, rent alone would have consumed three quarters of his pay – and that’s before bills. By saving his entire salary, he is building up funds for a future down payment on a house – a dream made possible only by having a job that comes with a home.

data.title: Germany’s rent controls ‘making housing shortage worse’
data.description:
Rent controls in Germany have worsened the country’s housing shortage and made it harder and more expensive for tenants to move, a leading economist has warned.

Restricting the monthly bill landlords can charge has undermined housebuilding, according to Clemens Fuest, the president of the Ifo Institute, and limited young workers’ ability to take a job in a new area.

Similar ideas have been proposed in Britain, with Sir Sadiq Khan, the Mayor of London, calling for the power to control rents amid the introduction of the Renters’ Rights Act, which comes into force in May.

“Rent control not only leads to less being built, but is also responsible for the rental market becoming increasingly frozen. In other words, fewer and fewer people are moving out of their rental property when it no longer meets their housing needs,” said Mr Fuest.

“The existing regulations protect tenants who have an apartment and no reason to move. This is at the expense of landlords and all prospective tenants looking for a rental apartment.”

Since 2013 rents in existing tenancies have risen by around 18pc amid tight restrictions on how much and how often landlords can raise the bill, the Ifo found. By contrast rates for new tenancies, which face fewer restrictions, are up by around 50pc.

In Berlin, the rent on new tenancies is capped at 10pc more than a local reference rate, though looser rules apply to short-term furnished lets, a segment of the market that has grown as a result.

The result is that the number of people moving dropped sharply between 2010 and 2020, the year for which the latest data is available.

During that decade – which included significant new restrictions on rents in major cities – the number of moves in urban centres fell from more than 85 per 1,000 inhabitants to around 66.

Mr Fuest said this threatened young adults’ job prospects and undermined growth in the wider economy.

“Young people in particular, who have found a job in another city and want to move, are increasingly reporting that they have failed to find accommodation,” he said.

“This is not only frustrating for those affected but also damages overall economic development. Economic growth only works if people can take up new jobs and move to do so.”

The Government in Berlin plans to extend and tighten rules capping rents in an effort to make monthly bills more affordable for tenants.

Mr Fuest urged the Government to focus on building more homes instead.

“The housing shortage in Germany can only be overcome if more housing is built and the existing housing stock is better utilised,” he said.

It is a similar problem to that in Britain, where annual rises in rents peaked at more than 9pc in 2024. In the past 12 months, the average rent increased by 3.5pc, according to the Office for National Statistics.

Despite the Government’s goal to build 1.5 million new properties in this Parliament, construction rates have been in decline.

Housebuilding in England fell to a 12-year low excluding the pandemic in the three months to September, with 30,880 homes completed.

Only 175,290 homes have been completed since the general election, well below the average 300,000 per year needed to meet the Government’s target.

London’s construction sector is particularly struggling to build more homes amid new regulatory requirements in the wake of the Grenfell Tower disaster.

A spokesman for the Mayor said he “has consistently called for the devolution of rent controls, which would enable us to develop a system that works for London and the unique challenges facing the capital”.

data.title: The City lender to Bangladeshi elite at the centre of a £900m fraud scandal
data.description:
Asked by Asian Voice to name his idols, Paresh Raja picked the villain from Oliver Stone’s 1987 film Wall Street and a mob boss from The Godfather.

“I can appreciate some of the drive behind Gordon Gekko and Vito Corleone, setting aside what it’s used for,” Raja told the publication in 2023.

It is a comment that he may now regret. Raja’s company, Market Financial Solutions (MFS), tipped into administration earlier this week amid allegations of fraud. Court documents seen by Bloomberg show a £930m black hole on its balance sheet.

The sudden implosion of the Mayfair-based private lender, or “shadow bank”, has sent shock waves through Wall Street and the City of London as lenders that backed the business scramble to work out how much they stand to lose. Bankers are already on edge following the high-profile collapse of two other private credit lenders.

The case has also resurfaced the lender’s links to the Bangladeshi elite. MFS was a significant backer of property deals struck by Saifuzzaman Chowdhury, Bangladesh’s former land minister. His property empire is now the subject of an investigation by the National Crime Agency (NCA). Authorities have not accused Raja or MFS of wrongdoing.

Raja, 58, founded MFS with his wife, Tiba, in 2006. The lender provided what it called “complex, property-backed lending”. The company’s main products included buy-to-let mortgages and bridging loans – short-term debt that borrowers could use for various kinds of investments in real assets.

MFS’s website stated that Raja was “committed to supporting property investors who encounter difficulties with – or are simply not suitable for – the high street banks”.

“We find ourselves regularly supporting borrowers who have been turned away on the high street,” Raja told Asian Voice. “We’re always happy to hear from those who may have missed payments on their record, who are based overseas, or who are looking to invest in less common property types.”

An important client of MFS during its rise was Chowdhury, Bangladesh’s former land minister. Companies linked to Chowdhury built up an impressive portfolio of properties in the UK during his five-year tenure in power before he and the government he was a part of were ousted in August 2024.

According to the Financial Times, Chowdhury-linked businesses took out hundreds of secured loans from lenders linked to MFS following his appointment as land minister in 2019.

After the fall of prime minister Sheikh Hasina’s regime in 2024, it appears that nearly all of the MFS-linked mortgages were repaid.

However, the property empire has become the subject of a National Crime Agency (NCA) investigation in the UK. In June, the NCA froze UK property worth £170m belonging to the former minister. Authorities have not accused Raja or MFS of wrongdoing.

At the time, lawyers for Raja said that MFS had “a large underwriting team who scrutinise every loan and carry out detailed and thorough anti-money laundering and other checks”. They emphasised that Raja “has no connection to Bangladesh or the Hasina government”.

MFS differed in important ways from mainstream banks. It was a shadow bank, meaning it offered loans but did not take deposits. As a result, it was not subject to the strict regulations that high street lenders must adhere to.

Before its collapse, the business appeared to be going from strength to strength. As of last March, it said it had secured an additional £1bn in capital from institutional investors, boasting a loan book of nearly £2.5bn.

Just 11 months before MFS tipped into administration, Raja said it was targeting a loan book of £3.5bn over the next year.

A sports lover who “regularly carves out time in his busy schedule to attend important sporting events”, MFS’s website said Raja travelled the world to watch football, cricket, Formula 1 and tennis.

He also spoke frequently to specialist finance media, tweeting as recently as December about his various appearances in the press.

‘Serious irregularities’

However, insolvency practitioners from Alix Partners were appointed this week after two companies linked to Market Financial Solutions, Amber Bridging and Zircon Bridging, alleged that there were “serious irregularities” in its finances.

According to Bloomberg, the pair accused MFS of using the same assets to back multiple loans, which may have led to an “unaccounted-for deficiency” of more than 80pc on £1.2bn of debts.

Approving the administration application this week, Justice Briggs said: “The allegations of fraud are very serious.”

“Mr Raja has failed to comply with the court order to appoint administrators and there is a need to protect assets available for creditors quickly,” the judge said, according to a report by debt industry publication 9fin.

At the time of the administration, Raja said the process did “not reflect a failure of the underlying business or the quality of our assets, but rather a technical and procedural impasse that has temporarily limited our access to everyday banking facilities”.

He added that it was “an extremely difficult moment for everyone connected with Market Financial Solutions”.

As AlixPartners sifts through the wreckage, analysts are already debating the scale of the losses that some of the biggest banks might face.

A cast of high profile banks including Santander, Wells Fargo, Jefferies and Barclays are understood to have funded MFS’s loans. Barclays, which has exposure of roughly £600m, had opened bank accounts for the company, but froze them in recent weeks.

Wall Street bank Jefferies is understood to have around £100m tied up in MFS, while Atlas, the structured-credit arm of Apollo Global Management, had £400m of exposure.

After MFS slipped into administration, shares of Jefferies slumped as much as 9.8pc, while Barclays fell by as much as 3.8pc and Apollo’s stock slid as much as 4.7pc.

Commentary from Citi suggested that losses for Barclays at least could be smaller than the initial figure of £600m, while BMO Markets noted that most of Jefferies’ loans weren’t processed by MFS itself, meaning losses could be lower.

Private credit fears

However, the crisis has shaken confidence at a time when the world of high finance is already on edge.

The allegations of fraud are reminiscent of two major collapses that rattled the private credit sector last year: US auto lender Tricolor Holdings and auto parts supplier First Brands Group.

Barclays has already booked losses on its loans to Tricolor, while Jefferies and Santander were both stung by the collapse of First Brands Group.

Credit markets have become increasingly spooked by a growing number of what Jamie Dimon, the boss of JP Morgan, described as “cockroaches”.

Dimon said earlier this week that he saw parallels between today’s markets and the era before the financial crisis.

“Unfortunately, we did see this in ’05, ’06 and ’07, almost the same thing – the rising tide was lifting all boats, everyone was making a lot of money,” he said. “I see a couple people doing some dumb things.”

Meanwhile, the fallout from property deals linked to Hasina’s Bangladesh government continues.

Authorities in Bangladesh are also looking into Chowdhury’s affairs amid a broader investigation into flats and houses bought by former allies and family members of the prime minister.

In Britain, Labour MP Tulip Siddiq, Hasina’s niece, resigned as Treasury minister in January last year amid growing pressure over the anti-corruption scandal in Bangladesh. Siddiq faces a corruption trial in Bangladesh over claims that she illegally received a plot of land from her aunt’s government. She denies the allegations.

Raja did not respond to a request for comment. The Telegraph was unable to reach Chowdhury for comment.

data.title: £70k on red tape and remediation: the true cost of home renovation
data.description:
When Sarah Hope embarked on a home improvement project, all she really wanted was a place to hang up the laundry.

Her modest ambition to keep the kitchen clear of drying clothes morphed into a six-figure renovation project. It also gave Sarah, 38, a crash course in the sheer complexity and expense of building in Britain.

Together with her husband Matthew, 42, the couple spent more than £60,000 on just the admin costs. This ranged from a £2,300 report on the history and heritage of their Victorian terrace to £16,000 in fees paid to Greenwich council.

This included the cost of licences for mandatory safety hoarding around the house, skips and a conveyor belt used to remove rubble.

This was on top of the usual cost of applying for planning permission, at £208, plus another £34 for the discharge of planning permission.

“I was like: ‘Are you joking?’” says Sarah. “It felt excessive, and I certainly wasn’t aware before we started that we’d need to do all of these things.

“All we wanted to do was modernise and improve the house to a really high standard, but they made it really hard.”

A spokesman for the council defended the amount of due diligence home improvers must undertake before being allowed to work in the borough. “The importance of good planning cannot be underestimated,” he said. 

“Basement extensions are complex builds. Documents such as a basement impact assessment are required to support these types of planning applications.

“But the cost of those documents – including a heritage statement – is for the applicant to negotiate and is completely unrelated to the council.”

The need for a heritage statement particularly irked Sarah. In order to install lightwells into the basement of their house, which is in a conservation area, they had to produce a 43-page document on the property and the local area’s history. 

“The thing is, you can’t see the lightwells from the street at all,” she adds. “They are down the side access, and no one can see them.”

Sarah is American and was living in New York when she met Matthew, a British lawyer, in 2015. Two years later, she moved to London and into Matthew’s flat in Maze Hill, south-east London, and the couple married. 

They both loved the neighbourhood, close to Greenwich Park and the River Thames, but by 2018, they wanted more space and decided to upsize locally to a house.

In November 2019, they paid £1.08m for their four-bedroom terrace. Although perfectly liveable, the couple was unimpressed by the kitchen. 

One wall was blocked by a large chimney breast, which meant all the cabinets were crowded into the other side of the room. By removing the chimney, they could rearrange the kitchen layout and add an island. They also set out to turn the former coal cellar into a basement utility room.

In April 2021, they hired LOUD Architects to help draw up plans for the house. During this period, they learnt that converting the coal cellar was going to be a complex task, involving digging out substantial amounts of earth and underpinning. 

“We started to think that it would only really be worthwhile if we dug out the full width of the house and did something bigger,” says Sarah.

They had their plans redrawn, this time with a full basement level with a utility room, shower room, spare room/gym and a wine cellar.

The immense preparation involved in getting all the necessary reports and licences together meant that work did not actually start on the house until December 2023. By then, Sarah had quit her day job to get the build started and project manage the work.

Early on, the contractor hired to dig out the cellar failed to turn up to work. Further investigation revealed the company had gone bust, still holding a £30,000 deposit from the Hopes. 

Matthew, now a partner at a US law firm, was able to put a strong case to the defunct firm’s legal representative, which resulted in 90pc of the money being repaid.

But Sarah is keenly aware that not everyone has a free lawyer on tap and must take a huge risk when paying large deposits out to firms with no guarantee of the quality of their work or even stay solvent long enough to carry it out. 

“We were very lucky,” she says.

There were other issues, such as an air conditioning unit being installed incorrectly. They were able to get their money back from the original workman, but to solve the problem, they had to pay a specialist firm to come in and assess it (£1,200) and then get it removed, repaired and reinstalled (£5,600).

In all, they lost £10,000 to vanishing building firms and snagging costs.

Sarah, Matthew and Copper, their fox red labrador, moved back into the house at the end of 2024. 

In the final analysis, the project – which increased floor space from 1,400 to just over 2,000sq ft – cost Sarah and Matthew £675,000, including more than £70,000 on red tape and remediation.

The bill was also high because building costs have spiralled since the pandemic. The cost of basics like bricks and plaster has increased by 20pc to 25pc, while the price of steel has doubled, according to Amit Patel of the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors. Labour costs have also doubled.

This means the Hopes’ total investment in their home, including the purchase, came to £1.76m. When remortgaging last year, the property was valued at £1.4m, although Sarah believes it would fetch more like £1.6m if it were to be sold. 

If she is correct, then it is the money they spent on preparation and resolving builder problems that has pushed them into the red.

“If you add up what we paid for the house and what we spent, yes, we have lost money,” says Sarah. “We intend to stay for at least five years, so it doesn’t really matter, but for a lot of people, it would make it impossible to modernise their homes.

“The UK has some of the oldest housing stock in Europe; our house is almost 150 years old, and it needs work to make liveable family homes. It was just a bit frustrating.”

A potential paper loss aside, Sarah, who now runs her own consultancy firm, is thoroughly enjoying the house. But, given her experience of getting a renovation project over the line, is it something she would ever do again?

After a long pause, the answer is a not-terribly-confident yes. 

“I need time, but maybe in five years, if we moved out of London, I would do another,” she says. “I probably would not do a lot of structural work again, but I do enjoy designing a space.”

data.title: Reeves accused of putting vital South West rail route at risk
data.description:
Rachel Reeves has been accused of putting South West England’s main rail route at risk by limiting maintenance spending while promising billions for Northern projects.

Fears are mounting that a sea cliff could collapse on to the line in Devon, cutting off Plymouth and the whole of Cornwall, after recent storms saw a sinkhole near the railway in Dawlish.

The cliff in question had been earmarked for £400m of earthworks after a 2014 collapse closed the line for eight weeks, costing the local economy £1.2bn.

However, the plan was abandoned after Labour sought to cut costs across the UK’s rail network. Instead, ministers suggested the cliff would be monitored for signs of movement. 

Storm Ingrid, which battered Devon two weeks ago, also saw waves destroy sections of a sea wall protecting the tracks at Dawlish, closing the line for two days.

Rebecca Smith, Tory MP for South West Devon, said the damage had stoked concerns that spending cuts had left the lifeline route exposed to potential disaster.

She said: “With all the tightening of the budget by the Chancellor, she has taken away contingency funding. So if there were something that needed an emergency reaction, the implication is that the money isn’t actually there.

“If you get the right kind of freakish storm, who knows what could happen. The question for me is, should this not be something that is in capital funding on a year-on-year basis?”

After Ms Smith asked in the Commons whether funding could be guaranteed for unplanned resilience work, James Murray, the chief secretary to the Treasury, said that budgets allow ministers to respond to emergencies.

He said: “All individual departments must recognise that unexpected pressures will come along; they need to prepare for them and make sure they have robust plans to respond.”

Ms Smith, a member of the transport select committee, said the Government’s reluctance to fund work on the cliff stood in contrast to its backing for the £45bn Northern Powerhouse Rail project, for which Ms Reeves last month announced £1bn of preparatory funding.

She said: “Why do they want to take a gamble when they are investing billions in other parts of the country? Why do we need a marginally faster rail system in the North when in the Southwest, if this went again, we’d be cut off for, I don’t know how long?”

Ms Smith also raised doubts about the level of monitoring that Network Rail is carrying out on the cliff, which is protected by the railway from the sea but prone to becoming sodden with surface water.

She said: “Are they monitoring it or just draining things? We need answers if they are not prepared to put the investment in to fix it.”

Martin Wrigley, Liberal Democrat MP for Newton Abbot, which includes Dawlish, said that had Storm Ingrid hit when seas were higher, the damage could have been much more severe.

He said the Department for Transport (DfT) should grant Network Rail money to undertake a study into a long-term solution for the cliff.

He said: “Monitoring is no good because the last collapse was a single, catastrophic failure, almost a tectonic shift of part of the cliff which came down on to the railway.”

Mr Wrigley said the damage to the Dawlish sea wall was also concerning, having affected areas on either side of a new section installed after the 2014 collapse.

The DfT said work carried out after the 2014 events held up well in the recent storms, with damage limited to a low wall between the coastal path and the railway. 

It said funding had been provided for a drainage trial and a range of advanced monitoring equipment, including tilt sensors that would provide a quick response if triggered.

Work will continue with Network Rail to assess the investment needed to ensure the line’s resilience and to develop any longer-term solutions.

data.title: ‘I thought I was on the phone to NatWest’s security team – but it was a scammer raiding my account’
data.description:
Mallika Basu was looking forward to a good 2026. The 48-year-old food writer was gearing up for a book launch – her first “actual, proper book”.

It took just a two-hour phone call to bring her hopes for the year crashing down. The mother-of-two from south London was scammed out of more than £5,700.

A couple of days earlier she had received a text which she thought was from her phone company, telling her to claim reward points she was owed. Basu clicked on the link and entered her card details as requested.

Worried she had done the wrong thing, she told NatWest that she thought her card might be compromised.

Then, on Jan 10, she received a strange text. The message asked her to approve a transaction of nearly £400 to eBay, which she knew nothing about. When she declined, she received a phone call.

It was the NatWest fraud team – or so she was told – and her account had been compromised.

“The first question I asked – because I’ve never been scammed in my life – was, ‘How do I know you’re calling from NatWest?’

“They said, ‘We are calling from NatWest, we would never ask for your pin and we would never ask for your password’. So they were mimicking what would normally happen,” she says.

The fraudsters convinced her that her money was unsafe and that it could be syphoned off to Pakistan, where it would be unrecoverable. Then they applied pressure – telling Basu that they couldn’t guarantee the safety of her money.

“They kept putting me on hold and saying, ‘We’re speaking to the security team. Because your account has been compromised online, we need to make sure that they can’t go in and apply for an overdraft or apply for a loan’,” she says.

She tried to move money out of her account – but the real NatWest recognised that she was being coerced quickly and blocked the attempted transactions. The fraudsters changed tack. If one account had been compromised then her other bank accounts could be too.

“Where else do you bank?” they asked.

Basu had personal and business accounts with online bank Starling: “They said: ‘Okay, well, NatWest has bought Starling and we have access. If you’re compromised on NatWest, you’re compromised on Starling too’.”

The food writer hadn’t heard of a takeover but she was convinced to move her money from Starling: “They got me on the basis of that to transfer my money urgently.

“Of course, now looking back, clearly they were following the path of least resistance,” she says.

The fraudsters would tell her whatever she needed to hear to trust them.

In three transactions, Basu moved more than £5,770 from her Starling business account. The first payment, through Western Union, was for £3,500. She was told that the money was going into a new, safe Starling account.

Basu claims that she did not give the fraudsters her Starling bank card details but the scammers were able to trigger card payments on her account, which came up as notifications for approval in her app. It is unclear how the scammers got this information.

“I did not set up the transactions. The transactions were generated. I was sent transactions to approve,” Basu says.

Starling says that Basu was shown 10 fraud warnings during the call, including ones which said that she was not on the phone to the bank. Basu says she has no recollection of the alerts.

She says: “If they’ve sent me in-app warnings, I am already lulled into a state where I am thinking, ‘Oh, it doesn’t matter, they’re protecting me’. So they’re essentially neutralising these warnings. I just don’t think it’s a very effective safeguard.”

Fraud has been rising, fuelled by AI and fake social media adverts with politicians, police forces and City regulators at a loss for how to tackle it. Britons lost more than £1bn to scams every year between 2020 and 2024, according to UK Finance. Another £630m was lost in the first half of last year.

Breaking the spell created by the emotional manipulation at the core of the scammers’ playbook is very difficult.

A three-year national fraud strategy – spearheaded by Lord Hanson of Flint, the fraud minister – is set to be published by the Home Office this spring. It comes after the launch of Report Fraud, which replaced the much-maligned Action Fraud.

Since October 2024, victims of authorised push payment (APP) fraud have been due reimbursement from their bank under a mandatory scheme overseen by the Payment Systems Regulator (PSR).

The latest figures showed that £173m was paid out by banks in the first year that the rules applied – or 83pc of the reported losses.

David Geale, the head of the PSR, told MPs at a Treasury select committee hearing earlier this month that the rules had been a “huge incentive” for banks to improve their fraud controls.

But the transactions that Basu had approved on her Starling app were card payments. This meant that she was not covered by the mandatory reimbursement rules, which only apply to Faster Payments or CHAPS – so, she has been left £3,500 out of pocket.

In letters seen by the Telegraph in response to her complaint, Starling said that it could have done more to stop the later transactions made by Basu, including another £2,160 which was sent just seven minutes later. It refunded around 40pc of the money she lost.

Basu questioned why Starling allowed any of the payments through at all, especially when NatWest had not.

The food writer says she was under a lot of stress because she was about to launch her book, In Good Taste. The scam emptied her business account.

She explains: “I was due to launch my first book which wasn’t a cookbook – the first time I’ve written an actual, proper book – in a week’s time. It was high stress.

“The pressure was immense and I was terrified that all my money would go [as the scammers told her].

“Of course it did. They got me. They took absolutely everything, I was left penniless basically.”

A spokesman for Starling said: “We understand how devastating this must be for the customer. Scams are a scourge and we make every effort to protect our customers from them.

“The customer was provided with 10 different warnings by our systems over the course of her transactions with the scammer. Six of these warnings required acknowledgement, which the customer gave before proceeding with the transactions.

“In this case, our transaction controls should have automatically blocked the second payment, even though the customer acknowledged the scam risks and wanted to proceed.

“While this scam is not covered by the PSR’s mandatory reimbursement rules, we have refunded the customer the second payment of £2,160 to Western Union as an acknowledgement that this payment could have been blocked by our systems.”

A spokesman for NatWest said: “We are glad we have been able to prevent Ms Basu from having her money stolen through a bank impersonation scam. At NatWest, we are using the latest tools and technology to catch and detect scams.

“We will never ask any customer to move money from their account to another account ‘to keep it safe’; this is one of the most common signs of a scam.”

data.title: Killer motorists should be treated like the murderers they are
data.description:
April 25 2007 is etched forever in my mind. It was a beautiful day, and summer was just around the corner. My twin sister had given birth to a baby boy, and my 65-year-old mother, Elizabeth, had come to stay with me in Mortlake, south London. We planned to go to the Chelsea and Westminster Hospital to visit the new baby.

My husband walked my two eldest children, Barnaby and Sapphire – who were six and four at the time – to school and then hopped on a train to work. My mother, my two-year-old daughter, Pollyanna, and I set off to catch the bus to the hospital.

My mother, who lived in rural Shropshire, loved London buses and much preferred them to the train.

We walked, with Pollyanna in her pram, the short distance from our house to the local bus depot. As we approached, Pollyanna climbed out of her buggy and held my mother’s hand.

This was when my life changed irreversibly. I turned around, and all I could see was a monstrous, red Metroline bus approaching at a ferocious speed. Instead of turning into the depot, it drove on to the pavement, aiming straight for us. It happened so fast – almost like a bomb going off.

My legs were trapped under the bus, and I was like the jam in the middle of a horrid sandwich – bus, me, wall. Blood was everywhere. I slipped in and out of consciousness. Out of one eye, I saw my darling, precious, beautiful mother slipping away. She did not survive.

Out of my other eye, I saw my little daughter about 20 ft away. She had been flung through the air, and her right leg was hanging off. I was trapped and could not help her. I shouted for my mother so loudly. I wanted her to answer me, but she did not. She could not.

The crash quickly flooded the news as my husband – The Telegraph’s Christopher Hope – received a call at work to tell him what had happened.

As he made the terrible journey from his office in Victoria to Mortlake, he did not even know if we were alive or not. Four surgeons spent seven hours trying to save Pollyanna’s leg, but they could not, and she had it amputated.

I suffered severe degloving in my leg (where skin and soft tissue is torn from the muscle or bone underneath), among other injuries. However, knowing that I would never see my mother again was the most unbearable wound.

The bus driver who hit us was found guilty of one count of death by dangerous driving and two counts of grievous bodily harm. He was sentenced to four years in prison, which is simply not long enough. Often, only aggravating factors like being under the influence of drink or drugs result in a longer sentence, but it is rare that criminal drivers get more than 12 years behind bars.

On average, four people die every day on UK roads, and many dozens more suffer life-changing injuries. It is no wonder that victims of road crime – like me – feel utterly let down by the UK’s criminal justice system.

Metroline would not speak to me when I rang up their head office. I felt upset, hopeless and angry. So, in February 2014, I set out on a mission – for road crime to be treated as real crime, and for victims and their families to be treated with kindness and compassion in navigating the criminal justice system.

I met Boris Johnson, who was the mayor of London at the time. He said he was very sorry for what had happened to my family. He asked me whether Transport for London (TfL) had apologised, and I said no.

He told me that must change. A few weeks later, my husband and I met with TfL and Metroline. They said they were very sorry. I said that “sorry” must hold meaning, and things began to change from then on.

The Sarah Hope Line was launched in February 2016. It is an incident line that offers confidential support to people involved in, or affected by, life-changing incidents on the TfL network. We have provided to more than 500 families what TfL did not give to us: trauma counselling, assistance with funeral costs and arrangements, and short-term accommodation for family members. Next Monday will mark our 10-year anniversary.

While the line supports families of the bereaved, we still have not yet changed the attitude within government that road crashes are “just one of those things”. This Government should spend much more on policing our roads, so that criminal drivers can be caught. We need to issue immediate fines and driving bans so motorists are deterred from driving dangerously.

Road crime and the damage it causes cost the taxpayer billions of pounds every year – it strains the NHS, criminal justice system and our emergency services. Fatalities, alone, cost the NHS billions every year. That money should be spent on policing our roads and preventing such devastation.

Perpetrators think they can get away with causing death by dangerous driving because sentences do not reflect the severity of the crime. Change must start now. We must no longer be the forgotten victims.

The Sarah Hope Line is on 0343 222 5678, Monday to Friday, 8am-6pm. For more details, go to https://tfl.gov.uk/travel-information/safety/incident-support-service

data.title: Heathrow boss: Airport isn’t crowded... foreigners just walk the wrong way
data.description:
The chief executive of Heathrow has said the airport is not crowded because foreigners just walk the wrong way.

Thomas Woldbye said people complain the airport is too busy when in fact people are just “crashing into each other”.

This is because European travellers are used to walking on the right, while the British walk on the left.

Mr Woldbye told an Aviation Club UK event on Thursday: “One of the reasons people think [Terminal 5] is crowded – it’s not, actually. But yes, people are in the wrong place.

“Problem is that all the British people keep to the left and normally Europeans keep to the right. And they do that in both directions. So we can be crashing into each other and I see that from personal experience.

“We just [need to] make sure that everybody going this way keeps going left, and [those] going this way keep to the right,” he added, gesturing with his hands to illustrate the different directions.

The humorous aside came after the Danish-born airport boss warned earlier this week that Heathrow could lose its coveted spot as Europe’s busiest airport to rivals such as Amsterdam or Paris unless a third runway is approved for construction.

Mr Woldbye said on Tuesday: “We remain Europe’s largest airport but latest figures show we may lose that position in 2026 and we cannot keep driving growth for the UK economy without more capacity.”

When asked what he thought of the Government’s position on the third runway, he said it was broadly supportive. But he added: “We don’t have long-term regulation, which is clear in terms of us building a business case.”

Last year, Heidi Alexander, the Transport Secretary, gave the go-ahead to Heathrow’s preferred plan to build a third runway over the top of the M25 motorway, a scheme likely to generate controversy over its cost and complexity.

The third runway scheme, which will see a 3,500-metre strip built to the north-west of Heathrow’s existing site, is currently estimated to cost around £49bn.

Included in the controversial plans are a scheme to build a 66,000-space car park at a cost of £2.6bn, as revealed by the City AM financial newspaper last summer.

The airport boss was also criticised on Thursday for raising drop-off fees paid by drivers to £7 – and threatening an £80 fine for motorists spending longer than 10 minutes saying goodbye to their loved ones.

He said in response to the criticism: “So when we make profits on all parts of the business, rather than just running the airport, that actually goes to reducing the charge [applied to passengers’ tickets].

“Whenever we make less money ... passengers are actually paying [for] that,” he added.

“We have an incentive to make as much money as we can, on the side, from anything that actually reduces the charge for passengers.”

Heathrow’s charges are regulated by the Government. The airport pays for its infrastructure by imposing a charge on airline passengers’ tickets.

Airlines, including Virgin Atlantic and British Airways, have set up a pressure group called Heathrow Reimagined, which calls for “urgent and fundamental reform” of this funding system.

data.title: Trump’s shadow looms large over Paramount’s Warner Bros triumph
data.description:
As Ted Sarandos jetted off to the White House from Los Angeles on Thursday, the Netflix boss was probably rehearsing a pitch on why his takeover of Hollywood’s most famous movie studios should be allowed to go ahead.

It turned out he would not need it. Just as Sarandos was sitting down for meetings with Trump’s officials, Warner Bros announced that it considered a rival $111bn (£82bn) offer from Paramount to be superior.

Having been usurped at the 11th hour, Netflix quickly folded, paving the way for a dramatic denouement to a saga that has gripped Tinseltown for months.

For Paramount, which is controlled by Larry Ellison, the Oracle billionaire, it signals the biggest victory to date in an ambitious plan to seize control of US media. Looming over everything, however, is the role played by Ellison’s “good friend” Trump.

As far as Hollywood takeovers go, the battle for Warner Bros has been nothing short of a blockbuster.

Skydance, the company led by Larry Ellison’s son David, sealed an $8bn (£6bn) takeover of Paramount last summer before quickly turning its attention to the real target: Warner Bros.

Paramount, which owns television channels such as Comedy Central and Channel 5, as well as the Paramount+ streaming service and its film studios, fired the starting gun by tabling an all-cash bid for Warner Bros in September. The move prompted David Zaslav, the Warner Bros chief executive, to put his company on the block.

In December, Warner Bros, which is behind franchises such as Harry Potter and Batman and also owns the HBO Max streaming service, home to hits such as Succession and The White Lotus, agreed to an $83bn takeover by Netflix.

Paramount refused to give up. The media group mounted an aggressive charm-offensive, preaching the advantages of its bid to politicians and regulators while highlighting the uncertainty surrounding the Netflix deal. It also threatened to mount a proxy fight on the Warner Bros board.

Warner Bros repeatedly rebuffed Paramount’s advances. Ultimately, however, the persistence paid off.

Warner Bros said this month it would give Paramount a week to submit its “best and final” offer, leading the suitor to increase its bid to $31 per share. Paramount also agreed to pay a so-called “ticking fee” of $0.25 per share for every quarter the deal does not close, a $7bn termination fee if the transaction does not gain regulatory approval and a $2.8bn break fee owed to Netflix.

On Thursday night, the board of Warner Bros threw its weight behind this $111bn offer. Netflix was given four working days to match the bid, but declined the opportunity. Co-chief executives Sarandos and Greg Peters said the deal was “no longer financially attractive”, insisting: “This transaction was always a ‘nice to have’ at the right price, not a ‘must have’ at any price.”

Politics heavily at play

Behind the eye-watering sums of money, politics has been heavily at play. While Trump ostensibly does not have a direct role in the deal, his interventions and sway over regulators are impossible to ignore.

Netflix had long acknowledged that its path to regulatory approval would be a tricky one, warning investors that it could take 18 months to get the deal cleared.

Trump’s department of justice had already launched a review into the takeover amid concerns that combining two of the largest US streaming platforms – Netflix and HBO Max – would harm competition.

Netflix also faced a fierce backlash from cinema operators and high-profile Hollywood figures such as James Cameron, the director of hit films such as Avatar and Titanic, who feared that the streaming giant would reduce the number of films released on the big screen. Netflix always rebuffed such claims.

Paramount, by contrast, has sought to downplay the regulatory risks of its offer, even as its swoop would reduce the number of Hollywood studios from five to four.

Here, politics has never been far below the surface – with Ellison’s links to Trump garnering much attention as the tycoon tightens his grip on US media.

Already, Paramount has snapped up The Free Press, an online media outlet founded by the high-profile “anti-woke” journalist Bari Weiss, and installed her as the head of CBS, which is now facing accusations of an aggressive shift to the Right. Ellison is also the linchpin of a conglomerate that bought up TikTok’s US assets. Trump has described the billionaire as a “good friend”.

News will play a crucial role in the merger. Unlike Netflix’s deal, Paramount is bidding for the entirety of the Warner Bros Discovery group, including its traditional networks. As a result, Ellison will control the news networks CNN and CBS.

Mark Thompson, the former BBC director-general who now leads CNN, urged staff not to “jump to conclusions” after Paramount emerged as the winning suitor.

Still, even without the news element, Trump had been particularly disparaging of the Netflix tie-up. Shortly after the deal was announced in December, he said the streaming giant had a “big market share” and that the combined company’s size “could be a problem”.

The row hit a fever pitch last weekend when Susan Rice, a former Obama adviser who sits on Netflix’s board, warned that Democrats would punish companies that “take a knee” to the president. Trump demanded that Netflix sack Rice or “pay the consequences”.

While navigating this tough landscape, Sarandos had sought to play down Trump’s influence. He told the BBC: “This is a business deal. It’s not a political deal.” He acknowledged, however, that the president “likes to do a lot of things on social media”.

Mike Proulx, an analyst at Forrester, said: “Politics are playing an outsized role in this deal, and they’ve been on Paramount’s side from the get-go.

“Even if Netflix hadn’t walked away, it was unlikely their deal would’ve made it through a politically charged regulatory process.”

‘Not a done deal’

While Warner Bros is now Paramount’s to lose – with the regulatory process likely to be smoother – the saga is yet to come to a conclusion. Rob Bonta, California’s attorney general, said on Thursday night that the takeover was “not a done deal” as he vowed to carry out a “vigorous” review.

Key to this will be the impact on the Hollywood economy. Paramount has said it will cut $6bn of costs, triggering concerns about heavy job losses. Sarandos has argued this will be followed by even deeper cuts as Paramount seeks to pay down heavy debt levels from its bid.

On Thursday, Elizabeth Warren, a Democratic senator who has called for a bribery investigation into Trump’s role in the Ellison takeover of Paramount, branded the company’s swoop on Warner Bros an “antitrust disaster”.

She said: “A handful of Trump-aligned billionaires are trying to seize control of what you watch and charge you whatever price they want. With the cloud of corruption looming over Trump’s department of justice, it’ll be up to the American people to speak up and state attorneys general to enforce the law.”

Meanwhile, concerns have also been raised over the vast sums of Gulf money bankrolling the Paramount deal. Sarandos branded foreign state ownership of media companies a “bad idea” this week.

Gulf ownership of media assets has been thrust into the spotlight in recent years after Abu Dhabi-backed fund RedBird IMI mounted an unsuccessful takeover bid for The Telegraph.

RedBird Capital, the US private equity fund that was the minority partner in the failed Telegraph takeover, is now helping to fund Paramount’s Warner Bros bid.

David Ellison could be forced to face up to these questions if he is called to a scheduled Senate antitrust hearing next week.

Netflix’s investors appear to have welcomed the streaming giant’s decision to back out of the complex and politically fraught deal. Shares jumped almost 9pc in post-market trading.

For now, the biggest winner of the saga is undoubtedly Warner Bros’s Zaslav, who is in line to pocket hundreds of millions of dollars from the sale.

The Warner Bros Discovery group, which was itself formed through a $43bn mega-merger in 2022, has seen its share price languish amid concerns about heavy debt and a decline in its traditional television business. On Thursday night, Zaslav hailed the deal as one which would create “tremendous” value for shareholders, adding that he could not wait to work with Paramount.

The Ellisons will probably be celebrating their biggest coup in an audacious empire-building spree across the US media. Yet the billionaires would be wise not to claim their victory too early.

With an unpredictable force in the White House, the Warner Bros saga could yet hold one final twist.

data.title: Denmark’s fat jab champion is slimming down the whole economy
data.description:
Novo Nordisk, Denmark’s fat jab pharmaceutical giant, reached an unwelcome milestone last week.

After a dizzying 76pc plunge in its share price over the past 18 months, a torrid week of trading meant it finally gave up the last of its market gains recorded since June 2021 when it released pioneering weight-loss drug Wegovy.

It follows years in which Novo Nordisk has been arguably Denmark’s greatest global success story. Its first-mover success with Wegovy and Ozempic turned it into Europe’s largest company, with the $100bn (£74bn) weight-loss drugs market at its feet.

The tide has since turned. This week, Novo admitted that its newest drugs were showing less promise in trials than those of its American rival Eli Lilly. It has also yielded to Donald Trump’s demand for hefty price cuts in the hitherto lucrative US market.

Novo is now in a metaphorical weight-loss programme of its own. It has shed its long-serving chief executive, cut 11pc of its workforce and lost hordes of foreign shareholders.

This is not a typical tale of corporate tumult. Novo is such a colossus in Denmark that its ructions can shake the country’s whole economy.

Yet Mette Frederiksen, the country’s Left-wing prime minister, chose this moment to take the country to an early election, set for March 24.

Since taking office in 2019, Frederiksen has steered Denmark through the turbulence of the pandemic, the Ukraine war and Trump’s threats to seize Greenland.

She will be hoping that Novo’s travails do not derail her bid for a third straight election victory.

It is something of a gamble. Novo’s fate is inextricably linked to that of the economy and thus to her own political prospects.

The company sold 309bn krone (£36bn) of drugs last year, which is more than 10pc of Denmark’s annual $430bn GDP. It employs one in every 100 Danes.

As Novo’s crisis deepened, Denmark’s economy – which was one of the fastest-growing in Europe – slowed dramatically at the end of last year. The country recorded 2.2pc growth in the third quarter, falling to just 0.2pc in the fourth.

Per Hansen, an economist at bank Nordnet, says: “One of the engines that has been driving the Danish economy over the past two to three years has been Novo Nordisk and the pharma industry.”

Las Olsen, the chief economist at Danske Bank, says that if you remove the pharmaceuticals sector, Denmark’s growth rate would be more like 1pc or 1.5pc.

“Which is fine, of course – but not the stellar growth rate that we have seen in the headline numbers,” he says. “I think we will grow more in line with European economies, perhaps a little less.”

These aren’t views that will cheer up the gloomy Danes.

Measures of Danish consumer confidence have languished in deeply negative territory ever since Russia invaded Ukraine.

“It’s a conundrum,” says Helge Pedersen, the chief economist at Nordea Bank. “House prices are at a record high, there’s almost no unemployment – everything is good but consumers are depressed.”

He says ordinary Danes are still preoccupied with inflation, even though the official rate is just 0.8pc.

“People are still worried about inflation, in particular food prices. We all discuss meat prices, they’re so high, coffee prices, chocolate prices. But that’s perceived inflation, which is higher than reality.”

Frederiksen and her centre-Left coalition partners have already started delving into the public coffers to soothe voters’ disgruntlement.

The Danish government recently cut the tax on electricity bills to almost zero. It also increased spending on childcare and welfare support and removed taxes on coffee, chocolate and sugar.

It has plenty of fiscal firepower. It was running a budget surplus estimated at more than 2pc of GDP in 2025 and its debt-to-GDP ratio was 30pc last year, one third that of Britain.

That allowed Denmark to ramp up defence spending last year by more than $4bn, which – along with higher healthcare expenditure – may prop the economy through any pharma slowdown.

The defence spending is a response to the Russia threat and also to pressure from Trump. He has called for Europe to fund its own defence and he is looking to wrestle at least de facto control over the Danish territory of Greenland.

Hansen says the Greenland issue may also have cast a pall over consumer confidence.

“Danish people are afraid that the new world order that is initiated by Mr Trump is something we have not dealt with since World War Two. That is really what is scaring the Danes,” he says.

Paradoxically, though, it may be helping the tough-talking and experienced Frederiksen. Since Trump’s Greenland manoeuvring became more explicit and tangible, her Social Democratic Party’s previously fading popularity has rebounded.

Geopolitical uncertainty and cost of living pressures are common across Europe. But in Denmark, there could be another more idiosyncratic source of economic anxiety.

Around 10pc of Danes hold shares in Novo. Many more will be exposed to its precipitous share-price decline via their private pensions.

Hansen, though, says Danish investors have been strangely patriotic: as foreigners have fled, Danes have been buying up the stock.

“The number of Danish private clients with us that hold one or more Novo Nordisk shares keeps climbing,” he says. “People still think there is a difference between what Novo Nordisk will achieve longer term and its current valuation in the stock market.”

Denmark’s economists, like its investors, also seem relatively sanguine about their country’s economic champion. Olsen says he was more worried during Novo’s breakneck growth phase than he is now.

“The fear was that it might erode the competitiveness of the rest of the economy. The large amount of hiring at Novo Nordisk could have led to very high base growth, that would then leave the rest of the economy uncompetitive if something was to go wrong,” he says.

“But what we have seen so far is that manufacturing wages growth in Denmark has, if anything, been lower over the last four or five years than we see in competitor countries. There is a competitive economy outside of Novo Nordisk.”

Pedersen agrees that the Danish economy is diversified enough to weather the Novo storm: “But of course you should keep an eye on it because the numbers are still so big on the macro level.

“Politicians do need to be aware that we have two Denmarks – one with and one without the pharmaceutical industry.”

Right now, the politician with the most riding on the Danish pharmaceuticals industry is Frederiksen.

As she called the election, she talked mostly about Greenland and wealth taxes.

Novo Nordisk’s decline might have garnered global attention with the company no longer deemed Denmark’s greatest success story.

Yet for Frederiksen, the hope is that this will simply be background noise as she bids for a third straight election victory – instead of a shot in the arm for her political rivals.
