data.title: ‘What does the RSC really need? A better train line to Stratford’
data.description:
I meet Daniel Evans and Tamara Harvey on the morning they announce their biggest coup to date – bringing Game of Thrones to the Stratford main stage this summer. The Mad King, a prequel play to the epic fantasy saga, has been written with the blessing and input of author George RR Martin. The news coincides, oddly, with the dramatic arrest of Andrew Mountbatten-Windsor (“Very Westeros,” Evans quips).

Have the two artistic directors of the Royal Shakespeare Company hit on the holy grail – the next Stranger Things: First Shadow, perhaps or Harry Potter and the Cursed Child? “That thinking is dangerous,” Evans, 52, counters. “The minute you think like that, you can jinx it.

“The reason we’re passionate about this is because it reads like a Shakespeare history play. It concerns leadership, succession, power, internecine fighting. George RR Martin is obsessed with Shakespeare.”

The globally successful HBO series (2011-19) was notorious for its scenes of sex and violence – it carried an 18 certificate in Britain. The prequel centres on the fabled Great Tourney [jousting tournament] at Harrenhal castle, and the tyrant king Aerys II Targaryen. “It’s going to be total theatre,” promises Evans of the production, which will be directed by Dominic Cooke (Hello, Dolly!). “There will be a content advisory, but we’re expecting it to be something the whole family can enjoy.”

The pair also tell me about the next wave of RSC programming for the autumn and winter which is announced today. This includes an all-male production of As You Like It (directed by Evans), Harriet Walter reprising her star turn as Brutus in a 90-minute version of Phyllida Lloyd’s acclaimed all-female Julius Caesar, plus a two-part adaptation of Middlemarch from Nina Raine. The year looks set to end on a swashbuckling high with The Three Musketeers, in which Dumas’s musketeers will be – gasp! – female.

Evans and Harvey, are a seamless and courteous double act. Having both enjoyed success running regional theatres (him: Sheffield and Chichester; her: Theatr Clwyd in Wales), they bonded during the stresses of the pandemic, and applied for one of the biggest jobs in British theatre on a joint ticket in 2022, succeeding Erica Whyman, who was briefly promoted from deputy after 10 years of Gregory Doran at the helm. Their tenure began properly in 2024. It’s full-on stuff, with Harvey, 48, talking about days that run from dawn to midnight, with her family commitments as a mother of two interspersed: “We often wish we could clone ourselves.”

In a departure from longstanding RSC man Doran’s methodical march through the canon, they have modified the approach so that it’s now more about bringing in diverse artistic talents with fresh, exciting ideas about what to stage, and how to stage it. As Harvey explains: “For us, there’s no point in putting on King John just because it hasn’t been done for a few years.”

The new rule is that there is no rule – anything could, conceivably, be an RSC show. While that approach might alarm traditionalists, it has reaped dividends in terms of ticket sales. More than 352,000 people attended productions in Stratford in their first year and The BFG last Christmas was the highest-grossing play in the history of the RSC. Rupert Goold’s Hamlet also played to 90 per cent capacity, while Kenneth Branagh’s imminent return to the RSC for the first time in more than 30 years in The Tempest has already sold out, just as Macbeth, starring Outlander’s Sam Heughan, did. Cyrano de Bergerac, starring Adrian Lester, is transferring to the West End this summer on the back of rave reviews.

A recent hit, Measure for Measure at Stratford, played fast and loose with the text – what do they think is acceptable in terms of tweaking texts many regard as sacrosanct? Evans tells me: “It’s OK to rewrite Shakespeare, but it’s not a free-for-all. Give us your rationale. The rule is that we’re not opposed to it. We’re not purists.” Harvey chips in with thoughts fresh from her rehearsals on Henry V, which she is about to bring to the Stratford main stage, with Alfred Enoch in the lead. “You can pick up any Arden edition and the footnotes read like a food fight between different editors,” she says. In her staging, too, she’s feminising some parts: “I didn’t want it to be a world where we assumed that almost everyone is male other than Katharine and Queen Isabel.”

One could easily spend an hour talking about Henry V (Harvey is, shockingly, the first woman to direct the play in the RSC’s history), but there are other serious matters to discuss.

Earlier this month, Trevor Nunn, the former RSC chief, stated that the RSC needed a London home; its purpose-built abode, the Barbican, is now one of a number of venues taking RSC work. “We are working out what London means for us,” says Harvey.

The more pressing task is transport to Stratford, which can seem Elizabethan in its remoteness. “To be frank,” Evans says, “a direct and better train service from London would be transformational. There used to be a direct train to Stratford [until 2023]. There no longer is. And we suffer because of it. When you look at theatre programmes from the 1960s, they used to have the last train time.” Could transport failure scupper their mission? “It might, because if we can’t get people to Stratford, how on earth are we meant to put on plays?”

That sounds quite existential, and behind the upbeat news there are clearly pressing challenges. Dividends reaped from ticket sales have not been substantial enough to mitigate the financial strain on the organisation, which is looking to reduce its workforce to achieve annual savings of £2.8m. In the autumn, the RSC announced that 420 of its 835 employees were eligible for voluntary redundancy – that consultation period is almost complete. The accounts for 2024-25 highlight the deficit problem: total income was £82m, substantially down on the previous year, with total expenditure running over £84m. Since then, annual repayments of the £20m Culture Recovery Fund loan taken out during Covid have kicked in, too. The drop in income partly reflects previous bumper takings at the box office – the 2022 Matilda film helped boost audiences for the stage show. But a cluster of factors are making life tougher.

“If you talk to most theatre leaders up and down the country, this is the case for them too,” Evans says. “Audiences have less money to spend because of the cost of living crisis. Costs have gone up exponentially. And there has long been a stand-still in Arts Council funding [currently approx £15m], which means a real-terms cut.”

There are no magic wands. Shows such as Les Misérables – which bankrolled the RSC for decades – are, he says, “like gold-dust – you’d be a fool to rely on them and part of the work we’re doing [in cutting back expenditure] is insulating the RSC from that reliance”. The desirability of any given corporate sponsor aside (and the RSC withdrew from a BP sponsorship deal in 2019 following protests), those options have dwindled, too: “There’s less money. Wherever the money comes from, there’s a deeper issue about relying on corporate sponsorship now.”

One option would be to scale back on productions, but that isn’t in their game plan, Harvey argues. “We have to find different ways of working but a sure-fire way to oblivion would be to reduce our artistic ambition and do less because then there’d be no point in our existing. You can cut back or you can be ever more ambitious and find different ways of making work and we’re going that route.”

There have been rumblings of discontent, particularly over plans to close the music department, with its in-house musicians. An online petition – attracting almost 7,000 signatures – has called for a rethink. If enough people complain, will they change their position? Harvey is swift to justify the proposed changes: “It’s about ensuring that music is more fully integrated into how we make work and giving composers the opportunity to work with freelance musicians. Some music will be created electronically, some will be recorded, some of it will be live.”

Upheavals notwithstanding, they’re looking to the future, with Evans (also an actor who left drama school early in order to join the RSC in the 1990s), hinting at repertory ensemble models. “We want to keep surprising audiences,” says Harvey.

As the actors bound back into the spacious Ashcroft room to resume rehearsals for Henry V, she leaves me with a final thought. Whenever the weight of responsibility presses hard, she confides, “I love to remember that this place exists because in the 1870s a local brewer and his son thought there should be a theatre in Stratford. The town and the theatre industry told them that they were mad but they understood that these plays survive because they’re performed. I love to remember that right at the root of this is a local brewer who had a radical idea, and the passion to see it through.”

Priority booking for all newly announced productions opens March 2 at 10am, with public booking opening March 18 at 10am. Priority booking for Game of Thrones: The Mad King opens April 14 with public booking from April 24. Info: rsc.org.uk

data.title: Advertising giant WPP to cut £500m in costs as it races to counter AI threat
data.description:
WPP plans to cut £500m in costs as the rise of AI threatens to upend the role of traditional agencies.

The London-listed media group said it aimed to achieve the savings target by 2028 by selling some of its businesses and consolidating its sprawling operations into four key pillars.

The savings will be reinvested in high-growth areas such as AI. The company previously said it would invest around £300m each year in WPP Open, an AI marketing tool that allows clients to create their own campaigns.

WPP and its rivals face an serious threat from the rise of the new technology, which could allow clients to sidestep traditional media companies altogether.

A number of high-profile brands including Coca-Cola and Heinz have already incorporated AI into their campaigns.

The technology still has the potential to misfire. Gucci has come under fire for using AI to generate images promoting its Milan Fashion Week show, with critics dismissing the results as “slop”.

However, the rapidly improving technology poses a significant threat and major advertising groups are scrambling to adapt to the new technology.

As part of the restructuring, WPP will restructure hundreds of ad agencies into four units: creative, media, production and the newly formed enterprise solutions.

WPP, which owns agencies including Ogilvy and Grey, did not say what impact the overhaul would have on staff numbers. The company has already been reducing headcount, with employee numbers dropping by almost 10,000 last year to 98,655.

Cindy Rose, the former Microsoft executive who became chief executive at WPP in September, is seeking to turn the advertising group around after a difficult period of declining sales and major client losses.

WPP’s shares have slumped 65pc in the last year to their lowest level since 1998, while the company has lost its crown as the world’s largest advertising company by revenue to French rival Publicis.

Ms Rose said WPP was an “extraordinary company” but admitted its performance was “just not where it needs to be”.

She added: “Our recent underperformance has been driven by excessive organisational complexity, a lack of an integrated operating model and inconsistent strategic execution.

“While disappointing, I see huge potential as these issues are all within our power to fix and we’re already making great progress.”

WPP’s revenue excluding pass-through costs fell by 5.4pc last year to £11.4bn, with headline operating profit falling by more than a fifth to £1.3bn.

Ms Rose hailed an improvement in winning new business but said revenue will continue to shrink in the first half of this year.

The simplification plans echo the strategy pursued by Ms Rose’s predecessor, Mark Read, who oversaw a major slimming down of the holding group’s network of agencies as it adapted to the growth of digital advertising rivals such as Facebook and Google.

data.title: US is best place to invest, says boss of British drugs giant
data.description:
The boss of Britain’s largest drug developer has praised the US as the best place to invest amid fears over the waning appeal of the UK.

Dame Emma Walmsley, the outgoing chief executive of GlaxoSmithKline (GSK), said it was delusional to suggest Britain could become a competitor to the US. She lauded America as key to the group’s future growth.

“It’s more than half of GSK’s global turnover today,” she said of the US. “It’s still the leading market in the world in terms of the launches of new drugs and vaccines. It’s still, probably alongside China … the best market in the world to do business development.

“No one should be deluded that the UK is going to be a massive scale market, a domestic market, but it can be an exporter of innovation in life sciences.”

Dame Emma said GSK, which spends £1bn developing new drugs in the UK every year, is preparing to invest $30bn (£23bn) in the US by the end of this decade.

She is set to leave GSK at the end of the year after eight years in charge.

‘Worst country in Europe’ for drug prices

Her comments are likely to fuel fears about the attractiveness of Britain’s pharma sector after several major drugmakers cancelled UK projects worth billions – amid concerns over NHS drug price rules and pressure from Donald Trump, the US president.

AstraZeneca recently announced it was pausing a planned £200m investment in a Cambridge research facility, while Merck scrapped plans for a £1bn research centre in London and laid off 125 scientists.

In September, Eli Lilly, the American manufacturer of weight loss drug Mounjaro, also said that it was reconsidering plans for Gateway Labs, its London-based hub that provides support for biotech startups.

The UK Government has struggled to revive overseas interest in Britain in recent years, with the number of foreign direct investment projects falling 12pc last year to a record low of 1,375, according to official figures.

High energy costs, recent pressures like the increase in employers’ National Insurance contributions and wider geopolitical uncertainty have all been cited as reasons for declining investment in the UK.

One of the key concerns of Britain’s pharmaceuticals industry has been over NHS drug pricing in the UK. 

After postponing its investment, Dave Ricks, the chief executive of Eli Lilly, said the UK was “probably the worst country in Europe” for drug prices.

The Government agreed to a deal with the US at the start of the month to scrap tariffs on UK drug shipments – in a bid to end the row with Britain’s pharmaceutical industry. 

Dame Emma welcomed the deal as “a step in the right direction” for Britain.

The agreement means the UK will pay more for medicines through the NHS, in return for a guarantee that US import taxes on pharmaceuticals made in Britain will remain at zero for three years.

data.title: Britain in danger of outsourcing its intellect, warns AI pioneer
data.description:
The artificial intelligence revolution threatens to erode Britain’s sovereignty, one of the country’s most experienced tech entrepreneurs has warned.

Ken Mulvany, co-founder and executive chairman of Benevolent AI, which has pioneered artificial intelligence in drug discovery, told The Telegraph that the United States and China are increasingly dominant in the crucial field.

He says: “If you look at this from the UK or Europe’s perspective, the risk is that these – China and America – are now the two cognitive powers. They’re the ones that are investing the most into this.

“I do worry about having the nation’s intellect effectively outsourced. It’s not just that, either. It’s the productivity gains.

“If for every hour of cognitive work that you do there’s a machine doing what would take you 50 hours, how do you as a nation compete with that?

“Electricity multiplied the power of muscles and AI can do the same with brains in certain scenarios. But it’s almost like you, as Britain and Europe are outsourcing national IQ to US and Chinese tech companies.

“So you’re left trying to regulate something you don’t own. And I do worry about that. I think of it as cognitive border control.”

Mulvany is better placed than most to sound the alarm. An eerily youthful 57 who betrays his Hawaiian roots with a surf-ready hairdo, he is an entrepreneur who has seen tech boom and bust more than once.

In a world increasingly haunted by visions of an AI apocalypse that would make the dotcom crash look like a minor market setback, Mulvany and Benevolent have already been tested to near-destruction.

The technology excited investors – including the star fund manager Neil Woodford long before his self-inflicted implosion – enough to snag a £1.5bn valuation way back in 2018.

This was long before the likes of Sam Altman of OpenAI and Dario Amodei of Anthropic emerged to seek thrones as the next generation of tech plutocrats.

Benevolent sought to help researchers to quickly design new drugs with computer assistance, using machine learning techniques to scour a treasure trove of science information for possibilities at an unprecedented clip. Expansion into defence and energy markets promised new horizons and riches.

It seemed to work. Benevolent burst onto the public markets long before the current AI frontrunners had attracted the attention of everyday investors, too. With the world still in the grip of the pandemic and having discovered an anti-inflammatory that was proving useful on pandemic wards, the start-up made a splashy debut.

“I wasn’t really part of it at that time,” Mulvany recalls ruefully. Having seemingly set up Benevolent for enormous success, he was already easing into semi-retirement.

As it secured a lucrative listing in Amsterdam, Benevolent won endorsement and investment from some of the pharmaceutical industry’s biggest names. AstraZeneca backed Benevolent as part of a transaction that raised hundreds of millions.

Alas, Mulvany’s big payday and exit did not set the scene for a sustainable company. A starry board and big executive hires steered Benevolent off a cliff.

The company lost almost all its value within two years, prompting Mulvany to abandon his early retirement and mount a boardroom coup to take back control last year. He had become frustrated that Benevolent had shifted from his concept of a technology company to a drug developer in its own right, with all the risk and costs associated with it.

“They brought in some luminaries,” Mulvany recalls. “Some really heavy hitters from pharma. And Benevolent morphed from a tech company to a pharma company. For me as an investor, and for some of my fellow investors, we didn’t have the appetite for that. We were technology investors.

“You had a technology shareholder base and a management and board doing biotech. All of its revenue was from its technology but it was spending a ton of money developing drugs.

“The technology cost was very low relative to drug development. So I became more of an activist shareholder at that point because it wasn’t going the way I wanted it to go and the markets reflected that too. It lost 95pc of its value.”

It’s a tale of hype meeting with financial and scientific reality that now seems to be playing out on an extreme scale as OpenAI and its rivals test the limits of pre-profit funding and investor patience. Altman alone has committed to spending more than $1tn (£750bn).

Having abandoned his retirement to mount his successful coup, Mulvany is now rebuilding Benevolent as an enterprise software company. Its new software and services are focused sharply on helping drug developers, rather than developing drugs. It’s a more commercial proposition, with a closer eye on returns for Benevolent and its big pharma customers.

“We help on the science side of things, reviewing the literature, but also how you make business decisions as a drug developer, how you expand into a particular market, how you design trials and all of that.

“People in the industry are making decisions with a fraction of the information they need.”

These are still the early days of Benevolent’s attempted comeback and Mulvany’s unexpected return from early retirement, which he had intended to spend skiing. His hopes of using the company’s targeted AI technology beyond drug discovery in fields such as defence and energy have been revived.

Benevolent, without revenue, now has the cash and investor support to pursue its new business into 2027, according to Mulvany.

Despite the mounting fears of an AI bust, he remains a believer in the technology. After a deep cull of staff, Benevolent’s coders are 50 times faster with the help of computer intelligence, for instance. But Mulvany, now an AI survivor, admits a shake-out lies ahead for those with grandiose visions.

“I saw this in the dotcom. I was there right at the bubble. But whether it’s railroads, or electricity or the internet there has always been over-investment and hype.

“So there’s going to be losers in this but the infrastructure is being put in place. So yeah, you’re seeing an AI bubble, but I’ve seen it before.”

data.title: Paramount raises bid for Warner Bros in attempt to block Netflix takeover
data.description:
Warner Bros has confirmed it has received an increased takeover bid from Larry Ellison’s Paramount, but suggested it was still in favour of a rival $83bn deal with Netflix.

The Hollywood studio said it was reviewing a revised offer from Paramount on Monday and would update shareholders once the review is complete.

But the company added: “The Netflix merger agreement remains in effect, and the board continues to recommend in favour of the Netflix transaction.”

Warner Bros did not confirm the details of the new Paramount offer. The Los Angeles-headquartered company had previously offered $30 per share, valuing Warner Bros at $108.4bn (£80.3bn).

The improved bid represents a late effort by Paramount to derail an $83bn takeover agreed between Warner Bros and Netflix last year.

The board of Warner Bros has repeatedly rebuffed Paramount’s advances, insisting that the Netflix deal offers superior value. A shareholder vote on the deal is scheduled for March 20.

But the company, which is behind major film franchises including the Harry Potter series, had agreed to give Paramount a week to submit its best offer or walk away.

Heated bidding war

Under the terms of its takeover deal, Netflix has the right to match any improved rival offer, raising the prospect of a heated bidding war.

Netflix has agreed to pay $27.75 per share for Warner Bros’s studio business and the HBO Max streaming service. By contrast, Paramount’s offer also includes the group’s traditional cable channels, including the CNN news network.

Paramount has previously sweetened its bid by offering to pay a so-called “ticking fee” of $0.25 per share to investors every quarter should its deal fail to close by the end of the year.

It also agreed to cover the $2.8bn termination fee Warner Bros would have to pay Netflix if it abandons their agreed deal, as well as $1.5bn in fees linked to Warner Bros’ debt refinancing.

The rival suitors have been locked in an escalating war of words, with Paramount seeking to highlight the regulatory uncertainty surrounding the Netflix takeover.

The US department of justice (DOJ) has launched a review into the deal amid concerns that combining two major streaming services – Netflix and HBO Max – would hand the company too much power.

Netflix has shrugged off concerns, saying the deal would lead to lower overall streaming costs for consumers. However, it has acknowledged that the regulatory process could take up to 18 months.

Paramount, which would also face regulatory scrutiny, last week said it had cleared a key hurdle with the DOJ.

Netflix has also faced criticism from the cinema industry amid fears the streaming giant could release fewer films on the big screen. James Cameron, the director of Avatar and Titanic, branded the deal “disastrous” in a letter this month.

Netflix has insisted it is committed to theatrical releases while Ted Sarandos, the co-chief executive, branded Mr Cameron’s comments “disingenuous”.

Foreign state ownership

Meanwhile, Mr Sarandos has hit out at Paramount over significant levels of Middle Eastern funding in its bid and claimed that foreign state ownership of media companies is a “bad idea”.

The Netflix chief criticised the involvement of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar in Paramount’s bid, highlighting restrictions on free speech in the Gulf states.

Speaking to the BBC, he said: “I think it’s a bad idea typically to have several sovereign wealth funds in that Paramount deal. Again, a part of the world that is not very big on the First Amendment.”

The sovereign wealth funds of the three Gulf states are contributing $24bn to Paramount’s bid – twice the amount committed by the Ellison family. RedBird Capital, the US private equity fund that was the minority partner in a failed takeover bid for the Telegraph, is also funding the bid.

Paramount has insisted that the sovereign wealth funds will forgo any governance rights, including board seats.

But Mr Sarandos dismissed claims that the Middle Eastern states would have no influence over editorial output.

He said: “It seems very odd to me with the level of investment that we’re talking about that they’d have no influence or editorial control over media in another country.

Alongside regulatory concerns, both Netflix and Paramount must also contend with Donald Trump’s interventions in the deal.

The US president this week called on Netflix to sack Susan Rice, formerly a senior official in Barack Obama’s administration, from its board or “pay the consequences”.

Mr Sarandos played down concerns about political interference, saying: “This is a business deal, it’s not a political deal.”

data.title: AstraZeneca to invest £11bn in China after snubbing Britain
data.description:
AstraZeneca has unveiled plans to invest $15bn (£11bn) in China just months after dropping hundreds of millions of pounds of investment in Britain.

The Cambridge-based company announced the investment, which will be used to expand its medical manufacturing and research capabilities, during Sir Keir Starmer’s visit to Beijing. The Prime Minister hailed the financing as a deal that would help to support British jobs back home.

But the announcement follows a period of frosty relations between the Government and AstraZeneca which has seen the drugmaker threaten to halt investment in Britain in a row over NHS pricing.

The pharmaceutical giant, which is Britain’s biggest listed company, has abandoned plans for a £200m expansion of its Cambridge research site and £450m overhaul of its Liverpool vaccine factory.

The deal may also raise eyebrows given that five of AstraZeneca’s staff were detained by authorities in China in 2024 amid claims of potential illegal activity. The president of its China division was subsequently placed under investigation by local police, with no further details provided.

Astra is the largest drugs company in China, which is the company’s second-biggest market after the US.

Separately, AstraZeneca also announced on Friday that it had struck a deal worth as much as $18.2bn with China’s CSPC Pharmaceuticals.

Under the tie-up, AstraZeneca will have the global rights to sell CSPC’s obesity drugs outside China.

CSPC is currently developing once-monthly weight-loss jabs. The biggest weight-loss treatments currently require people to inject themselves once a week.

In total, if all of CSPC’s eight obesity drugs make it to market, AstraZeneca said the deal could be worth as much as $18.2bn – including future sales of the weight-loss treatments.

Sir Pascal Soriot, the company’s chief executive, is one of a clutch of Western business leaders who are occasionally summoned for meetings with Xi Jinping, the Chinese premier.

Sir Pascal said on Thursday: “Today’s landmark investment of $15bn begins an exciting next chapter for AstraZeneca in China, which has become a critical contributor to scientific innovation, advanced manufacturing and global public health.”

The “landmark” move was recognition of China’s growing scientific capabilities in areas that could help unlock new treatments for cancer, haematological conditions and autoimmune diseases, among others. It will be focused on sites in Bejing, Shanghai, Wuxi, Taizhou and Qingdao.

Sir Keir said: “Unlocking opportunities for British businesses across the globe and delivering for working people back home is always the driving force behind my international engagements.

“AstraZeneca’s expansion and leadership in China will help the British manufacturer continue to grow – supporting thousands of UK jobs.”

Astra has been at loggerheads with the Government over how much the NHS pays for medicines.

The company and its rivals have argued that the way the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (Nice) evaluates “value for money” on medicines is flawed and deprives patients of potential breakthrough treatments.

For instance, Nice previously rejected Enhertu, Astra’s breast cancer drug.

Wes Streeting, the Health Secretary, walked away from talks with drugmakers last summer after failing to strike an agreement.

But in December, ministers announced a new deal with the US that saw Nice agree to pay up to 25pc more for treatments, a move aimed at protecting the UK life sciences industry.

data.title: Hope for run-down Boots as billionaire owner’s wife exits
data.description:
The British high street is experiencing its biggest cull in years.

Already reeling from a series of costly tax raids at the hands of Rachel Reeves, tough Christmas trading has proven to be the nail in the coffin for a string of struggling household names, including Claire’s, Russell & Bromley and LK Bennett. More high-profile casualties are expected in the coming weeks.

Amid the continued hollowing out of town centres, one high street stalwart remains: Boots.

Outposts of the lipstick-to-prescriptions business can still be found across the country, but many are in a sad state. After its exit from the stock market in 2007, Boots has spent the last two decades being starved of investment.

With serial dealmaker Stefano Pessina leading the charge, Boots has been allowed to dwindle – first under the ownership of private equity’s original Barbarians at the Gate, KKR, then as a forgotten overseas outpost of American pharmacy giant Walgreens.

Now Boots is in the hands of another private equity house, Sycamore Partners, after the New York-based outfit took Walgreens off the public markets last summer. Employees must fear yet more decline.

However, a shake-up at the very top of the company may signal a revival for one of Britain’s best-loved and most important retailers.

After leading the pharmacy giant for almost a decade, Boots chief executive Ornella Barra is stepping down to become chair. She replaces Pessina, who is also her business partner and husband, and is believed to still own half of the business at the ripe age of 84.

At the same time, managing director Anthony Hemmerdinger is being handed a much bigger role running Boots, including oversight of the No7 beauty brand – long regarded as one of several jewels in the stable.

The management reshuffle is viewed internally, and in the City, as another major step towards setting Boots free from its ownership purgatory and returning it to the UK stock market.

City sources said a float is still the main long-term ambition of the owners, and more likely to occur next year than in 2026.

A former executive said a spin-off of Boots “was always the plan” and the boardroom changes were “a step towards that”. The break-up of Walgreens into five standalone entities – Boots among them – shortly after its £8bn takeover last year was seen as the first real step.

The prospect of Boots being groomed for a spectacular public markets comeback under new leadership will raise hopes of a long overdue makeover of its unloved shops. Shoppers will be hoping that it also means a halt to any further closures.

The sale to Sycamore came after Boots axed 300 stores across the UK, drastically reducing its footprint from 2,200 to around 1,900 branches. Boots also shut 48 opticians in 2020, and had kickstarted a store closure plan the previous year that ended with more than 200 outlets being given the chop.

The status of Boots as more than just your typical bog-standard retailer means its future garners more attention than others.

Armed with Britain’s best-selling skincare brand No 7, the chain believes it can continue to compete in the booming beauty market despite the excitement surrounding the arrival of LVMH-backed French phenomenon Sephora in Britain, as well as other upstarts.

Amid the glamour of expensive lipstick and eyelash-thickening mascara, it is easy to forget that Boots is an integral part of the country’s healthcare system. Without its sprawling network of pharmacists, thousands of people would struggle to get their vital medicines and daily pills.

Its last round of store closures was accompanied by an apologetic statement explaining that the decision was “not taken lightly” and that in all cases there was an alternative store less than three miles away.

Yet that didn’t prevent an outcry in some affected towns, with locals complaining about being forced to endure long queues at other pharmacies, which in some cases had led to delays in getting their prescriptions.

Boots bosses have long rejected the portrayal of a business stuck in retreat as lazy and outdated.

“The Boots Group is in great shape, both financially and operationally, with Boots UK having grown market share for 19 consecutive quarters,” Barra said as she stepped aside.

But that fact masks the two-speed nature of the business. A former executive said there are around 500 Boots shops that are “the powerhouse of the business” – the vast majority of which have already been revamped.

However, the rest are much smaller shops, which are vital to the surrounding communities but cost “between £50,000 and £100,000” to refurbish with no resulting “uplift” in turnover, making it hard to justify the outlay.

“Pharmacies are really difficult to make money in now, because of what the Government pays per prescription,” another ex-director said. In November, the Department of Health and Social Care announced that NHS prescription charges would be frozen for the second year running.

 Clive Black, analyst at Shore Capital, adds: “There has been immense profiling of a small number of new and modernised stores, gaining lots of capital expenditure and senior management attention, to show the newfound vitality of Boots.

“But the reality is that many Boots are drab, under-invested, and needing of an injection of elevated execution that British shoppers will notice across the board.”

Those who know the business well say Boots branches need to become even bigger healthcare hubs, so that they can alleviate pressure on local GPs by providing more of the services that you would usually go to your doctor for.

The chain already does private online doctor consultations, vaccinations and blood pressure checks, as well as specialised treatments for skin and hair loss. However, it is eyeing a larger role in diagnostics with “at-home” testing kits for conditions such as high cholesterol, vitamin deficiencies and food intolerances. These will be offered under the mantra of standing “shoulder to shoulder with the NHS”.

If the move is successful, it would justify spending more capital on its smaller stores, many of which struggle to turn a profit.

The former executive says: “The mantra…was always ‘We’re going to have a great Boots in every major town, and none that we’re ashamed of.’ I think that will continue.”

data.title: Elon Musk’s satellite fix for mobile blackspots to cost £3 per month
data.description:
Millions of Britons will have access to mobile phone service in remote rural areas from Thursday as Elon Musk’s Starlink is rolled out for £3 a month.

The service, launched in partnership with Virgin Media O2, will boost mobile signals for O2 subscribers in remote, rural areas, allowing them to send WhatsApp messages and use apps such as maps, Find My Device and BBC Weather.

Mr Musk’s social media site X is also among a handful of compatible apps.

Customers will automatically connect to the satellite service, called O2 Satellite, which will expand the network’s coverage from 89pc to 95pc of the UK landmass, an increase roughly equivalent to an area two-thirds the size of Wales.

It will initially be available to customers with Samsung handsets, with plans to roll out to other devices, including iPhones.

O2 will charge contract customers an additional £3 a month for the service. Those on the most expensive Ultimate Plan will be able to access it for no additional cost.

The launch makes O2 the first UK mobile network to switch on its satellite service after Ofcom became the first regulator in Europe to approve the technology.

Vodafone plans to offer satellite services through its joint venture with Texas-based AST SpaceMobile. BT has struck a deal with Starlink to offer satellite broadband services and is exploring a similar tie-up for its mobile network EE.

Satellite technology has been touted as a key solution to fix patchy mobile coverage in remote, rural areas, though operators are keen to stress that it will not replace conventional mobile masts.

Mr Musk’s Starlink is also lined up to tackle poor signal on trains, while government officials are exploring its potential use in the emergency communications network used by Britain’s police, ambulance and fire services.

Starlink operates the largest satellite network for mobile services, with more than 650 satellites in low Earth orbit. Other competitors include OneWeb, which has merged with French rival Eutelsat following a £400m bailout by the UK Government, and Jeff Bezos’s Amazon Leo.

Lutz Schüler, the chief executive of Virgin Media O2, said: “This is a defining moment for UK mobile connectivity and a statement of our intent to keep innovating and ensure our customers can stay connected no matter where they are.”

Baroness Lloyd of Effra, the digital minister, said: “This is a major achievement for the UK and demonstrates leadership in next-generation connectivity.

“Being the first in Europe to launch direct-to-device satellite data services puts the UK firmly at the forefront of mobile innovation.”

data.title: Morrisons to sell dozens of pharmacies in scramble to cut costs
data.description:
Morrisons has put dozens of pharmacies up for sale in a fresh effort to cut costs.

The private equity-owned supermarket has launched a sale process after concluding that many of its in-store pharmacies are not financially viable.

As a result of the review, property agents have been tasked with selling some of the pharmacies on a store-by-store basis, rather than the entire portfolio.

Those affected are likely to remain open in stores, but under the brand of any eventual buyer.

The move to sell dozens of pharmacies comes after Morrisons’ losses plunged to £381m last year, fuelled by steep borrowing costs.

Rising debt pressures have led bosses to reduce borrowings, which fell to £3.1bn from £3.5bn last summer.

The sale of pharmacies is the latest attempt to strip back the business and focus increasingly on traditional retail.

A separate restructuring last year triggered the closure of four pharmacies, alongside 52 cafés, 17 convenience stores, 35 meat counters and 13 florists.

This led to more than 300 jobs being put at risk of redundancy, as bosses identified areas “where the costs of operations are significantly out of line with usage, volumes, or the value that customers place on them”.

Rami Baitieh, chief executive of Morrisons, said the cuts were a “necessary part of our plans to renew and reinvigorate Morrisons”.

Morrisons is pursuing a turnaround strategy after Mr Baitieh said the business had been going through a “challenging period”.

The retail boss blamed weaker consumer spending among poorer shoppers, many of whom have been affected by price rises.

This has led to Morrisons struggling to boost its share of the grocery market, which is at 8.4pc.

That is up narrowly from 8.5pc this time last year, although it is well below the 9.9pc it achieved in October 2021, when it was bought by private equity firm Clayton Dubilier & Rice in a £10bn deal.

This has prompted speculation that Morrisons could lose its position as Britain’s fifth-largest supermarket to Lidl, which now boasts 7.7pc of the grocery market.

Morrisons is not alone in seeking to sell off pharmacies, as the sector has been battered by rising costs in recent years.

Around 1,400 pharmacies have shut in England since 2017, according to the National Pharmacy Association, leaving many households unable to access medicine in their areas.

This has been blamed on rising wage costs and a shortfall in how much the NHS pays pharmacies.

Boots has also closed hundreds of pharmacies in recent years, while LloydsPharmacy, which had 138 sites, collapsed in 2023.

Rachel Reeves has piled more pressure on pharmacies over the past year by increasing business rates and the minimum wage.

Supermarkets have also come under pressure from rising taxes under Labour, most notably by the Chancellor’s decision to increase employer National Insurance rates.

Speaking last month, Mr Baitieh pleaded with the Government to avoid hitting retailers with any extra costs.

He said: “I would say, please, no more. This is very important for the market. We expect inflation to go up.”

Morrisons declined to comment.

data.title: ‘Significant’ squeeze on incomes hitting drinking, warns Guinness maker
data.description:
A “very significant” squeeze on disposable income is forcing Britons to cut back on drinking, the maker of Guinness has warned.

Diageo, which is one of Britain’s biggest pub suppliers, said the country’s economic malaise was the biggest factor in falling alcohol consumption.

Consumers are drinking “fewer servings per occasion”, the company said, although the number of times per month that people drank spirits in Britain rose by 16pc last year compared to 2024. Diageo also makes Smirnoff and Johnnie Walker.

A decline in drinking will add to pressure on Britain’s pubs, as they also grapple with tax raids and changing attitudes towards alcohol among young people.

Sir Dave Lewis, the new boss of Diageo, said: “These fewer serves per occasion point to a pressure in the economics that our consumer groups are facing.”

He added: “What you see is a very significant squeeze on disposable income.”

Sir Dave, the former boss of Tesco who was hired at the start of this year, said reinvigorating Diageo’s relationships with pubs and bars was one of his key priorities to turn around the struggling drinks maker.

He said the “on-trade” segment of its business – meaning sales into bars, restaurants, hotels and pubs – had been “dismantled understandably during Covid” but warned its “buildback has been slow and patchy”.

He was speaking as Diageo slashed its dividend in half, with Sir Dave adding there remained “significant work ahead” after he was forced to cut the company’s sales forecast.

Diageo reported a 2.8pc drop in underlying operating profits to $3.3bn (£2.4bn) in its half-year results as underlying sales also fell 2.8pc.

Sir Dave made the “difficult decision” to cut the dividend from 40.5 cents per share last year to 20 cents and ramped up cost savings to boost its flagging performance.

The prompt action helped the seasoned executive live up to his nickname “Drastic Dave”, earned during his three decades at consumer goods giant Unilever where he oversaw a programme of brutal but effective cost cuts.

However, the cost-saving plan and the weak sales wiped more than £5bn off Diageo’s market valuation on the London Stock Exchange, as shares fell by 13pc on their worst day ever.

The drinks giant also downgraded its full-year guidance for the second time in three months, with sales now expected to fall by between 2pc and 3pc because of ongoing troubles in the US. Profits are predicted to be flat or to rise by low single digits.

Sir Dave, who led a turnaround at Tesco from 2014 to 2020, said he was working on an updated strategy for Diageo, which he said he will unveil in the summer.

He was appointed at Diageo after a lengthy search for a successor to Debra Crew, who left in July following a rocky period of slipping sales and struggles to communicate a vision to both the board and market.

After performing strongly amid the rise of home drinking during the pandemic, Diageo has faced a cocktail of pressures in recent years. The company pivoted towards higher-end spirits and has battled shifting attitudes towards drinking.

More than a third of young people aged between 16 and 24 are shunning alcohol, the Health Survey for England revealed this year.

However, Guinness has attracted many new drinkers from Gen Z – driven by social media trends and growing popularity among young women.

On TikTok, trends such as “splitting the G”, where Guinness drinkers seek to down enough of their pint so the head of the beer bisects the company’s logo, have helped the brand go viral.

The Princess of Wales and Kim Kardashian are fans, and the company was forced to deny reports last year that it could capitalise on its popularity with a sale.

‘Significant opportunities ahead’

Sir Dave said: “Only several weeks in I can already see significant opportunities for Diageo to act more decisively to enhance its competitiveness and broaden the portfolio offering leading to higher growth.

“To deliver on these opportunities, we need to create more financial flexibility.

“Accordingly, the board has taken the difficult decision to reduce the dividend to a more appropriate level which will accelerate the strengthening of our balance sheet.

“We are confident that this is the right action which will ensure that Diageo can reinforce its position as the leading international spirits business and drive stronger shareholder value over the coming years.”

John Moore, of wealth manager RBC Brewin Dolphin, said Diageo’s results “reflect a company navigating near-term headwinds while positioning for longer-term recovery”.

“The headline might feel cautious this morning, but the real story will be in how Sir David Lewis articulates the path forward.”

Simon Hales, a Citi analyst, said the decision to more than half the dividend had “taken the shine off” the results, which could have “been seen as the clearing event for the stock to rally”.

data.title: John Lewis prepares to buy back supermarkets in retail push
data.description:
John Lewis is plotting to buy back some of its Waitrose supermarkets as part of a renewed push into retail.

Bosses are exploring the option of buying out landlords after building up a £1.5bn cash pile, confident that the company’s turnaround is progressing.

It marks a significant change in John Lewis’s fortunes after the company relied on its sale of a dozen Waitrose supermarkets in 2023 to raise £150m.

The strategy about-turn also sets John Lewis apart from some of its private equity-owned rivals in the retail sector.

This includes Asda and Morrisons, which have raised billions of pounds in recent years by selling off chunks of their estate.

Retailers often use sale-and-leaseback schemes to secure an immediate cash injection, although it then burdens businesses with long-standing rental costs.

It is not clear how many Waitrose supermarkets John Lewis wants to buy back, although a senior source said the business was taking an “opportunistic” approach.

There are more than 300 Waitrose stores across the UK, many of which are being upgraded as part of a £1bn investment programme. Including service station sites, airport shops and outposts in large John Lewis department stores, it has more than 400 Waitrose sites across the country.

John Lewis announced this month the acquisition of the freehold of the Hersham Green Shopping Centre in Surrey.

The prospect of buying back more Waitrose supermarkets comes after John Lewis abandoned plans to build 10,000 homes last week.

The withdrawal from its build-to-rent business is part of chairman Jason Tarry’s move to focus increasingly on the high street, rowing back from the botched diversification strategy pursued under predecessor Dame Sharon White.

The discussions over a buyback of its supermarkets will be viewed as part of a broader spending drive at the retailer, which is currently seeking to divert funds into areas that are fuelling its turnaround.

In an internal memo to staff, the retailer said it had set aside up to £12m to allow for bigger pay increases for head office workers with crucial skills or who are classed as key talent in its turnaround drive.

All salaried workers are expected to receive a minimum 2pc pay increase, but John Lewis said it would also allow managers to decide where to give extra wage rises.

Investment will go “where the need is greatest”, it said, with managers able to draw from the £12m pot.

It follows years where pay rises for head office teams have lagged those for shop floor workers, who were handed a further 6.9pc increase this year.

The partnership has been seeking to bolster its teams with top figures such as Tom Denyard, who joined as the new Waitrose boss from Tesco at the start of the year.

Mr Denyard has been tasked with helping to refresh Waitrose, including overseeing the £1bn investment into shops. Waitrose has set out plans to update 150 existing supermarkets over the coming years, as well as open scores of new stores.

John Lewis declined to comment.

data.title: Don’t let net zero purity tests sink the North Sea
data.description:
The North Sea is meant to be in managed decline. What we are seeing instead is a decline on fast-forward. In a world of rising energy demand, tighter public finances and intense geopolitical competition, Britain cannot afford to treat oil and gas as a moral litmus test rather than a pragmatic bridge to net zero.

Instead of extracting maximum value from our remaining resources, we are turning a home-grown strategic asset into a political symbol. Closing it down is presented as proof of seriousness on net zero. Yet we will still rely on oil and gas for decades.

We require realism about the energy system and about the fuels already embedded within it. The real question is simple: do we produce what we need at home, supporting British jobs, revenues and energy security? Or do we import more from abroad?

In today’s volatile world, that choice matters more than ever. Energy is once again a source of national power.

The US is using cheap domestic energy to attract industry. Norway continues to develop its oil and gas while remaining a climate leader. Meanwhile, Britain is debating whether to shrink its own production faster than demand declines.

We should be accelerating electrification as fast as possible. Transport, heating and industry must move on to clean power. And the electricity system must expand rapidly to support that shift. That is the only credible route to net zero and energy security.

But accelerating electrification does not mean pretending oil and gas will disappear overnight.

Start with the facts. Even under the Climate Change Committee’s most ambitious pathway, the UK will require 13 to 15 billion barrels of oil and gas between now and 2050. That would account for around 14pc of our energy supply.

Yet Britain is choosing dependency. We already import roughly half our oil and gas. Without fresh investment, that could rise to 80pc by 2030. By 2050, domestic production will meet only a fraction of what we still consume.

Even if we extracted every remaining viable barrel from the UK Continental Shelf – an estimated nine to 10 billion barrels – it would not meet projected demand. At best, we could cover around half our needs domestically. The rest would still be imported.

And imports themselves are not necessarily better. Gas shipped halfway around the world often has a higher carbon footprint than gas produced in UK waters.

The basin has been subjected to repeated short-term fiscal interventions – sudden tax rises, temporary levies and shifting allowances. The windfall tax has pushed headline rates to punishing levels, with some operators facing effective tax rates of more than 90pc.

The consequences are visible. Industry estimates suggest that £50bn of investment has been rejected or deferred under current conditions. Around 1,000 jobs are being lost every month across the sector. Capital is flowing elsewhere.

Yes, the levy raises revenue in the short term. But you cannot tax what is no longer produced. Accelerate decline and you shrink the future tax base, while bringing forward vast clean-up costs.

The UK faces between £40bn and £60bn in offshore decommissioning costs in the coming decades. Between £20bn and £30bn of that will ultimately fall to taxpayers through tax relief. Faster decline brings those bills forward while shrinking the revenue available to offset them.

Decline may be inevitable, but that doesn’t mean we should accelerate it. What the North Sea needs isn’t subsidy, but stability. A predictable fiscal framework would allow companies to invest, extend viable fields and manage decline responsibly.

That strengthens energy security, preserves skilled jobs and generates revenues to fund the transition.

There is still significant value left. Industry estimates suggest billions of additional barrels could be unlocked under stable conditions, potentially adding more than £100bn in economic value. That supports communities, strengthens the balance of payments and helps finance the clean technologies of the future.

None of this weakens Britain’s commitment to net zero. The 2050 target must stand. Climate change is real and dangerous. But cutting domestic production faster than demand falls does not reduce global emissions. It simply shifts supply elsewhere.

Even under Clean Power 2030, substantial gas capacity will remain in the system to keep the lights on when the wind does not blow. Gas does not disappear because it’s politically inconvenient.

Using domestic resources pragmatically, while building nuclear and other firm low-carbon power, isn’t a retreat. It’s realism.

An energy strategy built on climate theatre will not endure. If electricity remains expensive, if industry relocates and if public consent fractures, climate policy will falter.

The North Sea isn’t a relic. It’s a strategic asset in managed decline. Used wisely, it can strengthen energy security, support jobs and generate revenues while we build the low-carbon system of the future.

Wind it down prematurely and we don’t eliminate demand. We export it.

Tone Langengen is senior energy policy adviser at the Tony Blair Institute

data.title: Warner Bros says Paramount bid may top Netflix deal
data.description:
Warner Bros has signalled it could back Paramount’s revised takeover offer before a deal already agreed with Netflix.

The Hollywood studio said on Tuesday a revamped $31-a-share offer from Paramount could “reasonably be expected” to lead to a superior proposal to a deal agreed with Netflix late last year.

Paramount’s new offer values Warner Bros at around $112bn (£83bn) and includes a promise to pay a $2.8bn termination fee that the Hollywood studio would be required to pay to Netflix for ending the current agreement.

The offer also includes a “ticking fee” of $0.25 per share for every quarter the deal doesn’t close and a $7bn termination fee if the transaction does not gain regulatory approval.

The improved bid represents a late effort by the billionaire Ellison family to derail an $83bn takeover of Warner Bros by Netflix, which was agreed in December.

Paramount, which is controlled by David Ellison and his tech billionaire father Larry Ellison, has made repeated approaches to try and force the Warner Bros board back to the table and last week won the right to make a best and final offer.

The studio behind The Godfather now appears to have made Warner Bros an offer that would be hard to refuse.

Warner Bros said the Netflix agreement remained in effect and the board would continue to recommend that transaction – a recommendation it would not withdraw or modify for now.

However, if Paramount follows through with its promised offer, the board signalled it may be deemed superior. Netflix will then have four business days to make its own counter offer.

It raises the prospect of a potentially intense takeover battle for Warner Bros, following a months-long pursuit of the studio by both bidders.

Paramount’s stock rose just more than 1pc in after-hours trading. Netflix shares also rose 1.2pc. Warner Bros Discovery shares edged down 0.8pc on the added uncertainty about any deal.

A shareholder vote on the deal is set for March 20.

Netflix has agreed to pay $27.75 per share for Warner Bros’s studio business – which is behind hits such as Harry Potter, and the HBO Max streaming service, known for Succession. Paramount’s bid also includes the studio’s traditional cable channels, such as CNN.

Paramount has stressed the regulatory risks of Netflix’s bid. The US department of justice has launched a review of the deal amid concerns that combining two major streaming services – Netflix and HBO Max – would hand the company too much power.

Netflix has downplayed concerns, though it acknowledged that the review could drag for a year and a half.

For its part, Netflix has criticised the involvement of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar in Paramount’s bid, highlighting restrictions on free speech in the Gulf states. The Middle Eastern nations are contributing $24bn to Paramount’s bid – twice the amount committed by the Ellison family. Paramount insists the Gulf states will not have governance rights.

data.title: HSBC hands out bigger bonuses in push to rival Wall Street
data.description:
HSBC is handing its best bankers bigger bonuses as it seeks to compete with Wall Street rivals.

Senior investment bank staff received an average bonus of $819,000 (£606,000) last year, up 11pc compared with 2024. The overall pool of bonuses also increased by 10pc to $3.9bn, the highest in at least a decade.

Georges Elhedery, HSBC’s chief executive, said: “We are building a high-performance culture. It’s a culture where talent succeeds. It’s a culture where talent and performance are better rewarded and differentiated in the way we reward them.”

At the same time, HSBC reportedly intends to withhold bonuses entirely from its poorer performing staff, as it moves towards an “eat-what-you-kill” stance similar to its competitors in the US. Awarding bankers a dreaded “doughnut” – zero bonus – is seen in the industry as a humiliation.

In an attempt to improve performance and shake up the culture at the 160-year-old bank, Mr Elhedery has been swinging the axe.

The banking giant said it had cut the ranks of managing directors by 15pc over the last year, helping it meet a £1.1bn cost-cutting programme half a year early.

Many of the job losses have come from the combination of HSBC’s commercial banking, global banking and markets businesses last year. The merger led to a number of duplicated roles being axed.

Mr Elhedery, who was handed £6.62m in 2025, up from £5.58m last year, announced cost-cutting plans last year that included an 8pc reduction in payroll costs.

In total, HSBC’s employee numbers fell from 221,000 to just over 218,000 over the last year. However, pay and benefits rose from $20.2bn to $21.5bn over the same period.

The bank’s full-year results showed a pre-tax profit of $29.9bn for the year. That analysts’ estimate of $28.9bn was down 7pc compared to the prior year.

Shares in the bank rose more than 5pc on the FTSE 100.

Since taking over as chief executive, Mr Elhedery has led a radical restructuring of the bank. Along with cutting staff numbers and merging divisions, he has also doubled down on his predecessors’ focus on Asia.

The bank has shuttered some of its banking divisions in the US, the UK and Continental Europe and has taken private its troubled Hong Kong subsidiary Hang Seng Bank, as it looks to benefit from growth in the Asian financial hub.

Its business in Hong Kong saw revenue rise by 6pc to $15.9bn, while its UK division saw revenue rise by 5pc to $12.9bn.

data.title: Hinkley Point C nuclear power station costs rise to £48bn
data.description:
The cost of the Hinkley Point C nuclear power station has surged to more than £48bn and will reach £50bn if it faces further delays, warned its developer, EDF.

The cost of the project has risen from an estimated £41bn to £46bn predicted two years ago – on the back of surging inflation and delays that have added to the power station’s expenses.

It means Hinkley Point C will have cost EDF the equivalent of nearly £1,800 for every UK household by the time it starts operating, which will now be no earlier than 2030.  

The new estimated cost was revealed by the French energy giant in its latest accounts. The extra expenses are mainly due to problems with electromechanical work: the wiring and plumbing needed around the reactors, which are now in place.

If that work hits further snags, project costs will rise by at least another £1bn, EDF has warned. Given inflation will push all these prices up, Hinkley’s final cost is now all but certain to exceed £50bn.

When first planned a decade ago, Hinkley C was predicted to cost £18bn and to start operations around 2025.

However, the project’s expenses has ballooned since then, as the delivery timeline has slipped.

EDF said the project would cost between £25bn and £26bn in 2024 and be delivered in 2027. The developer then warned that costs had risen again in 2024, and said that a four-year delay would not see the first reactor operating until at least 2029.

EDF now says the first reactor will not start generating until 2030 at the earliest.

The project has proven controversial for France’s state-owned generator as successive delays and cost overruns caused its debt to balloon.

The state-owned utility’s difficulties at Hinkley threaten to increase its financing needs as the company prepares to begin construction on six new reactors in France, while continuing to fund UK projects.

Added costs

EDF is on the hook for the construction costs at Hinkley Point C, but the power it produces will be some of the UK’s most expensive at a predicted price of £150 per megawatt hour – well over double the market price.

The costs would have been higher still, but EDF was able to charge £1.6bn to the parallel Sizewell C nuclear power project for “Hinkley C project expertise”, meaning the transfer of lessons learnt at Hinkley to avoid similar costs and delays.

EDF is also involved in constructing the Sizewell C nuclear station, which is at a much earlier stage and is predicted to cost about £40bn. However, EDF has reduced its stake in that project to just 12.5pc, with the UK Government holding 44.9pc and most of the risk.

EDF runs the UK’s remaining fleet of five nuclear power stations, each with two reactors. Its accounts reveal that a fall in prices and a prolonged outage at one of its nuclear power stations dragged on UK profits last year.

The company said nuclear output from its five active power stations decreased by 12pc last year. Its Sizewell B facility in Suffolk and Torness in Scotland had a strong performance, but was hit by an extended outage at the Hartlepool power station in Durham.

The station, in Teesside, North East England, began generating power 43 years ago and provides enough electricity to power around two million homes. It was given a further one-year extension to generate electricity until March 2028, one year later than previously expected.

But outages affecting one of its two reactor systems were the main driver of EDF’s overall drop in nuclear output last year. The group’s net income fell to €8.4bn (£6.9bn) last year from €11.4bn in 2024.

data.title: Waitrose to stop selling mackerel
data.description:
Waitrose is to stop selling mackerel because of concerns about overfishing in British waters.

The supermarket said all fresh, chilled and frozen mackerel will disappear from its counters and shelves by April 29. Pâté is also being dropped, while tinned mackerel will be available only until the current stock has sold out.

Instead, Waitrose will be promoting smoked herring and cured sea bass as “tasty alternatives”.

Waitrose is the first major UK supermarket to stop stocking mackerel. It comes after the International Council for the Exploration of the Sea, which helps governments manage their fish stocks, last year called for a 70pc reduction in mackerel fishing, warning stocks were dangerously depleted.

Jake Pickering, the head of agriculture, aquaculture and fisheries at Waitrose, said: “By suspending sourcing of mackerel at Waitrose we are reinforcing our ethical and sustainable business commitments, acting to tackle overfishing and protect the long-term health of our oceans and this crucial fish.”

Mackerel populations in the north-east Atlantic are now at their lowest level in more than 20 years.

The UK, Norway and the Faroe Islands recently agreed to cut mackerel catches by 48pc but observers have warned that this is not enough to allow populations to rebound. The European Commission warned in December that the deal “poses serious risks for the sustainability of the mackerel stock”.

Mr Pickering added: “Our customers trust us to source responsibly, and we are closely monitoring the fishery. We look forward to bringing mackerel back to our shelves once it meets our high sourcing standards.”

The supermarket said it would start stocking mackerel again if and when fish stocks recover.

Mackerel, an iridescent oily fish with a strong flavour, is high in Omega-3, which is known to be good for the human brain. However, Omega-3 oxidises very quickly, meaning that the fish goes rotten if not preserved or eaten fresh.

They are often grilled, barbecued or made into pâté. For generations, they have been an easily-caught species by children and adult anglers alike.

In Rick Stein’s fish cookery book, Fruits of the Sea, the TV chef wrote of mackerel: “The taste takes me right back to my childhood in Cornwall, when we used to go out feathering for mackerel around Padstow or the Scilly Isles.”

Because of the spoilage risk, the fish is most often sold smoked. Smoked mackerel is often turned into pâté, blended with crème fraîche or cream cheese.

“Smoked mackerel pâté is a fairly new delicacy that has become popular in the last four or five years,” Jane Grigson, the influential British cookery writer, wrote in her 1971 cookbook, Good Things.

Since then, it has become a modern classic and is often served as a dinner party canapé or starter.

Britons buy around 33,000 tonnes of mackerel a year. This is far lower than 200,000 tonnes brought ashore annually by the UK fleet, with much of Britain’s mackerel exported to France and Spain.

The UK also currently allows foreign vessels, such as Norwegian boats, to catch mackerel in British waters, which contributes to overfishing.

Almost all of Waitrose’s mackerel is sourced from Scotland.

While sales of fresh fish have stagnated in recent years, demand for tinned fish is rising. Brands such as Ortiz and Sea Sisters have proved popular with Gen Z and millennials thanks to their retro packaging and striking logos.

Waitrose said it would promote smoked herring, smoked peppered herring and smoked sea bass as mackerel alternatives.

The supermarket will also introduce frozen sardines in May as a sustainable replacement for frozen mackerel.

data.title: Paramount wins bidding war for Warner Bros after Netflix walks away
data.description:
Paramount has won the bidding war for Warner Bros, after its 11th-hour bid prompted rival Netflix to pullout.

Netflix on Thursday night walked away from an $83bn deal for Warner Bros after Paramount, controlled by the billionaire Ellisons, convinced the Hollywood studio to back a rival deal.

Warner Bros Discovery (WBD) said its board of directors had concluded that a $31-a-share offer from Paramount constituted a “superior proposal” to the Netflix transaction.

The streaming giant was given four working days to make its own counter offer. However, shortly after Netflix said it would back out of the deal instead.

Co-chief executives Ted Sarandos and Greg Peters said in a joint statement: “We’ve always been disciplined, and at the price required to match Paramount Skydance’s latest offer, the deal is no longer financially attractive, so we are declining to match the Paramount Skydance bid.

“We believe we would have been strong stewards of Warner Bros.’ iconic brands, and that our deal would have strengthened the entertainment industry and preserved and created more production jobs in the US. But this transaction was always a ‘nice to have’ at the right price, not a ‘must have’ at any price.”

Netflix shares climbed 10pc higher after the announcement was made.

It marks a stunning victory for billionaire Larry Ellison and his son David, who runs Paramount. The Ellisons, close allies of Donald Trump, have been building a media empire in recent years and had seen acquiring Warner Bros as a key part of their plans.

Paramount has been seeking to derail the Netflix bid since the start of the year, making unsolicited counter offers and stressing the regulatory risks involved in the current deal. 

Earlier in the week Warner Bros, the studio behind the Harry Potter franchise and recent hits including Sinners, had signalled that it was minded to endorse the latest Paramount bid.

The Los Angeles-headquartered company’s latest proposal values Warner Bros at around $112bn (£83bn) and includes a promise to pay a $2.8bn termination fee triggered by walking away from the Netflix deal.

The offer also includes a “ticking fee” of $0.25 per share for every quarter the deal doesn’t close and a $7bn termination fee if the transaction does not gain regulatory approval.

David Ellison, chairman and chief executive of Paramount, said on Thursday night: “We are pleased WBD’s Board has unanimously affirmed the superior value of our offer, which delivers to WBD shareholders superior value, certainty and speed to closing.”

Paramount said the Ellison Trust would provide $45.7bn of equity towards the deal, backstopped by Mr Ellison’s tech billionaire father Larry. Bank of America Merrill Lynch, Citi and private equity giant Apollo have agreed to provide $57.5bn of debt.

Shares in Paramount rose just more than 5pc in after-hours trading and Warner Bros Discovery shares fell 2pc.

Last December, Netflix agreed a deal to pay $27.75 per share for the Warner Bros’s studio business along with the HBO Max streaming service, known for shows such as Succession and White Lotus. The transaction would see Warner Bros’s cable business, which includes channels such as CNN, spun off as a separate business.

By contrast, Paramount’s offer is for the whole company.

The US Department of Justice (DOJ) had launched a review into the Netflix takeover amid concerns that combining two major streaming services – Netflix and HBO Max – would hand the company too much power.

Netflix had downplayed concerns, though acknowledged that the review could drag for a year and a half.

It had criticised the involvement of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar in Paramount’s bid, highlighting free speech restrictions in the Gulf states. Paramount insists the Gulf states will not have governance rights.

Both sides have been lobbying in Washington to garner support for their bids. 

Mr Ellison, the Paramount chief, attended Mr Trump’s State of the Union address as a guest of Republican Senator Lindsey Graham earlier this week. 

Separately, CNBC reported Netflix chief Ted Sarandos visited the White House on Thursday to discuss the takeover with President Trump.
